https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equa:
Title: Cubic equations of state

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state

Published Time: 2021-12-05T23:04:19Z

Markdown Content:
Cubic [equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state "Equation of state") are a specific class of thermodynamic models for modeling the pressure of a [gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas "Gas") as a function of temperature and density and which can be rewritten as a [cubic function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_function "Cubic function") of the [molar volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molar_volume "Molar volume").

Equations of state are generally applied in the fields of [physical chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_chemistry "Physical chemistry") and [chemical engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_engineering "Chemical engineering"), particularly in the modeling of [vapor–liquid equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium") and chemical engineering [process design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_design "Process design").

Van der Waals equation of state
-------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Van der Waals equation of state")]

The [van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation") of state may be written as

![Image 1: {\displaystyle \left(p+{\frac {a}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)=RT}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3545f5b9a338f5970242895d661973388b7002bf)
where ![Image 2: {\displaystyle T}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0) is the [absolute temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_temperature "Absolute temperature"), ![Image 3: {\displaystyle p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36) is the [pressure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure "Pressure"), ![Image 4: {\displaystyle V_{\text{m}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ebf08323d371313a802f0c3aafa5e61059d1afef) is the [molar volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molar_volume "Molar volume") and ![Image 5: {\displaystyle R}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4b0bfb3769bf24d80e15374dc37b0441e2616e33) is the [universal gas constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_gas_constant "Universal gas constant"). Note that ![Image 6: {\displaystyle V_{\text{m}}=V/n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/83b3269d215fa4c4b75020d4bed9e962034d1752), where ![Image 7: {\displaystyle V}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/af0f6064540e84211d0ffe4dac72098adfa52845) is the [volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volume "Volume"), and ![Image 8: {\displaystyle n=N/N_{\text{A}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e5dc8e39e5426bc1fa57c94813777922736a723), where ![Image 9: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b) is the number of moles, ![Image 10: {\displaystyle N}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f5e3890c981ae85503089652feb48b191b57aae3) is the number of particles, and ![Image 11: {\displaystyle N_{\text{A}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/037f8d054f445451d8fee1b440cddba989e66ea1) is the [Avogadro constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avogadro_constant "Avogadro constant"). These definitions apply to all equations of state below as well.

Proposed in 1873, the van der Waals equation of state was one of the first to perform markedly better than the ideal gas law. In this equation, usually ![Image 12: {\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc) is called the attraction parameter and ![Image 13: {\displaystyle b}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f11423fbb2e967f986e36804a8ae4271734917c3) the repulsion parameter (or the effective molecular volume). While the equation is definitely superior to the ideal gas law and does predict the formation of a liquid phase, the agreement with experimental data for vapor-liquid equilibria is limited. The van der Waals equation is commonly referenced in textbooks and papers for historical and other reasons, but since its development other [equations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state "Equation of state") of only slightly greater complexity have been since developed, many of which are far more accurate.

The van der Waals equation may be considered as an ideal gas law which has been "improved" by the inclusion of two non-ideal contributions to the equation. Consider the van der Waals equation in the form

![Image 14: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cb8f4c4e9b72dee675fd629535aeef1f8115ee13)
as compared to the ideal gas equation

![Image 15: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8609ac9cd413649a8460ae18566334e55d9595e8)
The form of the van der Waals equation can be motivated as follows:

1.   Molecules are thought of as particles which occupy a finite volume. Thus the physical volume is not accessible to all molecules at any given moment, raising the pressure slightly compared to what would be expected for point particles. Thus (![Image 16: {\displaystyle V_{\text{m}}-b}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cafc345a1ce025bb687661490ddb5662c9dde2a2)), an "effective" molar volume, is used instead of ![Image 17: {\displaystyle V_{\text{m}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ebf08323d371313a802f0c3aafa5e61059d1afef) in the first term.
2.   While ideal gas molecules do not interact, real molecules will exhibit attractive [van der Waals forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_force "Van der Waals force") if they are sufficiently close together. The attractive forces, which are proportional to the density ![Image 18: {\displaystyle \rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f7d439671d1289b6a816e6af7a304be40608d64), tend to retard the collisions that molecules have with the container walls and lower the pressure. The number of collisions that are so affected is also proportional to the density. Thus, the pressure is lowered by an amount proportional to ![Image 19: {\displaystyle \rho ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/95b44a36e828a576858671546f5e0cb05806b742), or inversely proportional to the squared molar volume.

The substance-specific constants ![Image 20: {\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc) and ![Image 21: {\displaystyle b}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f11423fbb2e967f986e36804a8ae4271734917c3) can be calculated from the [critical properties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_properties "Critical properties")![Image 22: {\displaystyle p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f22f743ffb43cb8d64ef095c95ab2f86d9a631fe) and ![Image 23: {\displaystyle V_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2898d8bcbfbf7f2f6785c81f989dac1e6b1d9520) (noting that ![Image 24: {\displaystyle V_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2898d8bcbfbf7f2f6785c81f989dac1e6b1d9520) is the molar volume at the critical point and ![Image 25: {\displaystyle p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f22f743ffb43cb8d64ef095c95ab2f86d9a631fe) is the critical pressure) as:

![Image 26: {\displaystyle a=3p_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a85975e0a6332826e20442523f32dbf25e41f28c)![Image 27: {\displaystyle b={\frac {V_{\text{c}}}{3}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e1360942e84c3376b1e960ece27b307a9c309cf5)
Expressions for ![Image 28: {\displaystyle (a,b)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d7e5710198f33b00695903460983021e75860e2c) written as functions of ![Image 29: {\displaystyle (T_{\text{c}},p_{\text{c}})}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e345edfc07546af933a7fd6394f1e01d23ae250c) may also be obtained and are often used to parameterize the equation because the critical temperature and pressure are readily accessible to experiment.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-1) They are

![Image 30: {\displaystyle a={\frac {27(RT_{\text{c}})^{2}}{64p_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4cd3f93f8c4174f09c42e4e7cbb36d4918c6f3c8)![Image 31: {\displaystyle b={\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{8p_{\text{c}}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/20dc2008f6ea422c48864b80aef088ba13c9d6d4)
With the reduced state variables, i.e. ![Image 32: {\displaystyle V_{\text{r}}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/be546e50ec7f7f12fc5442ae36bcb7017293b4ae), ![Image 33: {\displaystyle P_{\text{r}}=p/p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e9382a954869f06f41337624d55437b6d5d765f0) and ![Image 34: {\displaystyle T_{\text{r}}=T/T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/156638893d04e6efbd4e6a02ff25ae35238c99c7), the reduced form of the van der Waals equation can be formulated:

![Image 35: {\displaystyle \left(P_{\text{r}}+{\frac {3}{V_{\text{r}}^{2}}}\right)\left(3V_{\text{r}}-1\right)=8T_{\text{r}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0d950bdb9521ec2595da7a14ed603a01822ffd75)
The benefit of this form is that for given ![Image 36: {\displaystyle T_{\text{r}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/229cf03fc200625dd0404b5ebffc0de0cc75f59d) and ![Image 37: {\displaystyle P_{\text{r}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8586a05a79b6782a12d46933e3a8b83cae8f2a7a), the reduced volume of the liquid and gas can be calculated directly using [Cardano's method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_formula#Cardano's_method "Cubic formula") for the reduced cubic form:

![Image 38: {\displaystyle V_{\text{r}}^{3}-\left({\frac {1}{3}}+{\frac {8T_{\text{r}}}{3P_{\text{r}}}}\right)V_{\text{r}}^{2}+{\frac {3V_{\text{r}}}{P_{\text{r}}}}-{\frac {1}{P_{\text{r}}}}=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0604610ac49d9b2b0b10cabc529406a51f71af4b)
For ![Image 39: {\displaystyle P_{\text{r}}<1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78e37434b3aca7d6b2adde77df7740649679307c) and ![Image 40: {\displaystyle T_{\text{r}}<1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ede9d87bf983c6c3b5e36d8d777087f82019a50b), the system is in a state of vapor–liquid equilibrium. In that situation, the reduced cubic equation of state yields 3 solutions. The largest and the lowest solution are the gas and liquid reduced volume. In this situation, the [Maxwell construction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell_construction "Maxwell construction") is sometimes used to model the pressure as a function of molar volume.

The [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor")![Image 41: {\displaystyle Z=PV_{\text{m}}/RT}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b6b710f2ec2936ee84733f078e6e253dd62d8ca2) is often used to characterize non-ideal behavior. For the van der Waals equation in reduced form, this becomes

![Image 42: {\displaystyle Z={\frac {V_{\text{r}}}{V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {1}{3}}}}-{\frac {9}{8V_{\text{r}}T_{\text{r}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/956cdcd4293375478ad62a39c89916e572ce3b1f)
At the critical point, ![Image 43: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}=3/8=0.375}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/290b834bb8ea88683697c3d8f164a092c03b68d0).

Redlich–Kwong equation of state
-------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Redlich–Kwong equation of state")]

Introduced in 1949,[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:1-2) the [Redlich–Kwong equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state "Redlich–Kwong equation of state") was considered to be a notable improvement to the van der Waals equation. It is still of interest primarily due to its relatively simple form.

While superior to the van der Waals equation in some respects, it performs poorly with respect to the liquid phase and thus cannot be used for accurately calculating [vapor–liquid equilibria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibria "Vapor–liquid equilibria"). However, it can be used in conjunction with separate liquid-phase correlations for this purpose. The equation is given below, as are relationships between its parameters and the critical constants:

![Image 44: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}p&={\frac {R\,T}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{{\sqrt {T}}\,V_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)}}\\[3pt]a&={\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{\frac {5}{2}}}{p_{\text{c}}}}\approx 0.42748{\frac {R^{2}\,T_{\text{c}}^{\frac {5}{2}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\\[3pt]b&={\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\approx 0.08664{\frac {R\,T_{\text{c}}}{p_{\text{c}}}}\\[3pt]\Omega _{a}&=\left[9\left(2^{1/3}-1\right)\right]^{-1}\approx 0.42748\\[3pt]\Omega _{b}&={\frac {2^{1/3}-1}{3}}\approx 0.08664\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3d70c2ada5cfdc99033ee5bbe2e719afa426f05a)
Another, equivalent form of the Redlich–Kwong equation is the expression of the model's [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor"):

![Image 45: {\displaystyle Z={\frac {pV_{\text{m}}}{RT}}={\frac {V_{\text{m}}}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{RT^{3/2}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/69a73552396dd506a9fcd0dd83b41d833d6c291d)
The Redlich–Kwong equation is adequate for calculation of gas phase properties when the reduced pressure (defined in the previous section) is less than about one-half of the ratio of the temperature to the reduced temperature,

![Image 46: {\displaystyle P_{\text{r}}<{\frac {T}{2T_{\text{c}}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2c741624da4c74f600cddae630bb0548e0084f7b)
The Redlich–Kwong equation is consistent with the [theorem of corresponding states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_of_corresponding_states "Theorem of corresponding states"). When the equation expressed in reduced form, an identical equation is obtained for all gases:

![Image 47: {\displaystyle P_{\text{r}}={\frac {3T_{\text{r}}}{V_{\text{r}}-b'}}-{\frac {1}{b'{\sqrt {T_{\text{r}}}}V_{\text{r}}\left(V_{\text{r}}+b'\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e960b11ebe7f43700c030c549fce2bbad04d4465)
where ![Image 48: {\displaystyle b'}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cee8dc8bb1c6c5c94066d54504f57177d11883c7) is:

![Image 49: {\displaystyle b'=2^{1/3}-1\approx 0.25992}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e9e1522b4115d8e5903110c7e39c2fb7283867bc)
In addition, the compressibility factor at the critical point is the same for every substance:

![Image 50: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}={\frac {p_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}}{RT_{\text{c}}}}=1/3\approx 0.33333}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bc012b6c249248164dd7f533695d23db104bac58)
This is an improvement over the [van der Waals equation prediction of the critical compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation#Compressibility_factor "Van der Waals equation"), which is ![Image 51: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}=3/8=0.375}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/290b834bb8ea88683697c3d8f164a092c03b68d0) . Typical experimental values are ![Image 52: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}=0.274}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/43e7e7033e23e2bd7fd26d88cba8eb83b837825e) ([carbon dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_dioxide "Carbon dioxide")), ![Image 53: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}=0.235}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/115bbcedbd5d3f7975e5a386175fb28fde052ae4) ([water](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water "Water")), and ![Image 54: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}=0.29}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3cc75e84c517a9ae90a5bd3ff0425c480d402732) ([nitrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrogen "Nitrogen")).

Soave modification of Redlich–Kwong
-----------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Soave modification of Redlich–Kwong")]

A modified form of the Redlich–Kwong equation was proposed by Soave.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Soave_modification_of_Redlich-Kwong-3) It takes the form

![Image 55: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a\alpha }{V_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/445bcea54d6613536473ffe2279925e857ee4fde)![Image 56: {\displaystyle a={\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}={\frac {0.42748\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/faffd7f86a7824ca815bed28756101e91798976b)![Image 57: {\displaystyle b={\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}={\frac {0.08664\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a32b8d992dab39d64ccf0caeb041c259809c6413)![Image 58: {\displaystyle \alpha =\left(1+\left(0.48508+1.55171\,\omega -0.15613\,\omega ^{2}\right)\left(1-T_{\text{r}}^{0.5}\right)\right)^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/74983628023320e90d23ee791f083ea83dd20817)![Image 59: {\displaystyle T_{\text{r}}={\frac {T}{T_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3f99e1a75d0f403759ebddefb3728a0224b058d)![Image 60: {\displaystyle \Omega _{a}=\left[9\left(2^{1/3}-1\right)\right]^{-1}\approx 0.42748}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1eb00b42186221ded220a2ad5d51066b472a55c6)![Image 61: {\displaystyle \Omega _{b}={\frac {2^{1/3}-1}{3}}\approx 0.08664}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/091dbfac960812e3cab6729a97c31096d4bdd3a3)
where _ω_ is the [acentric factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acentric_factor "Acentric factor") for the species.

The formulation for ![Image 62: {\displaystyle \alpha }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b79333175c8b3f0840bfb4ec41b8072c83ea88d3) above is actually due to Graboski and Daubert. The original formulation from Soave is:

![Image 63: {\displaystyle \alpha =\left(1+\left(0.480+1.574\,\omega -0.176\,\omega ^{2}\right)\left(1-T_{\text{r}}^{0.5}\right)\right)^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0462b39327872862df8866964f3169ca1679d396)
for hydrogen:

![Image 64: {\displaystyle \alpha =1.202\exp \left(-0.30288\,T_{\text{r}}\right).}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/371a4b19239b524599e9ae57a5be3429209d461c)
By substituting the variables in the reduced form and the [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor") at critical point

![Image 65: {\displaystyle \{p_{\text{r}}=p/P_{\text{c}},T_{\text{r}}=T/T_{\text{c}},V_{\text{r}}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{c}},Z_{\text{c}}={\frac {P_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}}{RT_{\text{c}}}}\}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/290d1b1614cfb72f2c4205f252c1d1178f872a73)
we obtain

![Image 66: {\displaystyle p_{\text{r}}P_{\text{c}}={\frac {R\,T_{\text{r}}T_{\text{c}}}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}-b}}-{\frac {a\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c+}}b\right)}}={\frac {R\,T_{\text{r}}T_{\text{c}}}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}=}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/194fe3f5e502904253c38f47f636a795667def83)![Image 67: {\displaystyle ={\frac {R\,T_{\text{r}}T_{\text{c}}}{V_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}^{2}\left(V_{\text{r}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}\,RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}={\frac {R\,T_{\text{r}}T_{\text{c}}}{V_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}^{2}\left(V_{\text{r}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1efae25be70cd7e16236fad03bd5759c822c90b1)
thus leading to

![Image 68: {\displaystyle p_{\text{r}}={\frac {R\,T_{\text{r}}T_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}V_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}\,R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}^{2}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}V_{\text{c}}^{2}\left(V_{\text{r}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}={\frac {T_{\text{r}}}{Z_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}}{Z_{\text{c}}^{2}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}\left(V_{\text{r}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/da7a7deec50ddfbab8054205427a2fdbde747c2e)
Thus, the Soave–Redlich–Kwong equation in reduced form only depends on _ω_ and ![Image 69: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fdda522a39ec48be84f41026323ebff84fbab480) of the substance, contrary to both the VdW and RK equation which are consistent with the [theorem of corresponding states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_of_corresponding_states "Theorem of corresponding states") and the reduced form is one for all substances:

![Image 70: {\displaystyle p_{\text{r}}={\frac {T_{\text{r}}}{Z_{\text{c}}\left(V_{\text{r}}-{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}-{\frac {{\frac {\Omega _{a}}{Z_{\text{c}}^{2}}}\alpha \left(\omega ,T_{\text{r}}\right)}{V_{\text{r}}\left(V_{\text{r}}+{\frac {\Omega _{b}}{Z_{\text{c}}}}\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/916a048d84ee6a11dcbc1f15a6c0179aac7992ba)
We can also write it in the polynomial form, with:

![Image 71: {\displaystyle A={\frac {a\alpha P}{R^{2}T^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/42406f8e08c61d3300a27a131a47d2c6f855621a)![Image 72: {\displaystyle B={\frac {bP}{RT}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4c4e108a2f405e1dd39927a208e537c9cfe07092)
In terms of the compressibility factor, we have:

![Image 73: {\displaystyle 0=Z^{3}-Z^{2}+Z\left(A-B-B^{2}\right)-AB}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c5214cfabfdde2bac36a2c551ab26a3d80ed2da5).
This equation may have up to three roots. The maximal root of the cubic equation generally corresponds to a vapor state, while the minimal root is for a liquid state. This should be kept in mind when using cubic equations in calculations, e.g., of [vapor-liquid equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium").

In 1972 G. Soave[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-4) replaced the ![Image 74: {\textstyle {\frac {1}{\sqrt {T}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/85c37374de4ba7376995a08752e79811932252e6) term of the Redlich–Kwong equation with a function _α_(_T_,_ω_) involving the temperature and the acentric factor (the resulting equation is also known as the Soave–Redlich–Kwong equation of state; SRK EOS). The _α_ function was devised to fit the vapor pressure data of hydrocarbons and the equation does fairly well for these materials.

Note especially that this replacement changes the definition of _a_ slightly, as the ![Image 75: {\displaystyle T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7533bdfb188e7d7458b73217d5358d1a18baf53f) is now to the second power.

Volume translation of Peneloux et al. (1982)
--------------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Volume translation of Peneloux et al. (1982)")]

The SRK EOS may be written as

![Image 76: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m,{\text{SRK}}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{V_{m,{\text{SRK}}}\left(V_{m,{\text{SRK}}}+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a15b5e8e6c5074e46400063dc76b296bea7839aa)
where

![Image 77: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&=a_{\text{c}}\,\alpha \\a_{\text{c}}&\approx 0.42747{\frac {R^{2}\,T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\\b&\approx 0.08664{\frac {R\,T_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6dc2bc1d1f3eed7d8cb613ee43a64166fdcace17)
where ![Image 78: {\displaystyle \alpha }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b79333175c8b3f0840bfb4ec41b8072c83ea88d3) and other parts of the SRK EOS is defined in the SRK EOS section.

A downside of the SRK EOS, and other cubic EOS, is that the liquid molar volume is significantly less accurate than the gas molar volume. Peneloux et alios (1982)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Peneloux1982-5) proposed a simple correction for this by introducing a volume translation

![Image 79: {\displaystyle V_{{\text{m}},{\text{SRK}}}=V_{\text{m}}+c}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a5beed3aff2e84f5f41d801c3b13beae70d66fbb)
where ![Image 80: {\displaystyle c}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/86a67b81c2de995bd608d5b2df50cd8cd7d92455) is an additional fluid component parameter that translates the molar volume slightly. On the liquid branch of the EOS, a small change in molar volume corresponds to a large change in pressure. On the gas branch of the EOS, a small change in molar volume corresponds to a much smaller change in pressure than for the liquid branch. Thus, the perturbation of the molar gas volume is small. Unfortunately, there are two versions that occur in science and industry.

In the first version only ![Image 81: {\displaystyle V_{{\text{m}},{\text{SRK}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5bb457be64f1b9680147e05e30013e010ba3d265) is translated,[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Soave1990-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Zeberg2001-7) and the EOS becomes

![Image 82: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{\text{m}}+c-b}}-{\frac {a}{\left(V_{\text{m}}+c\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}+c+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78e1ca1dc7f4301055b62485ba6dc941b2e15aef)
In the second version both ![Image 83: {\displaystyle V_{{\text{m}},{\text{SRK}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5bb457be64f1b9680147e05e30013e010ba3d265) and ![Image 84: {\displaystyle b_{\text{SRK}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4cd2fa4c72915236b8d23bd5e738b35130beb5c0) are translated, or the translation of ![Image 85: {\displaystyle V_{{\text{m}},{\text{SRK}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5bb457be64f1b9680147e05e30013e010ba3d265) is followed by a renaming of the composite parameter _b_ − _c_.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Pedersen1989-8) This gives

![Image 86: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}b_{\text{SRK}}&=b+c\quad {\text{or}}\quad b-c\curvearrowright b\\p&={\frac {R\,T}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{\left(V_{\text{m}}+c\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}+2c+b\right)}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a96a417be26a39b4d97a72da8d6db9a657e8068d)
The _c_-parameter of a fluid mixture is calculated by

![Image 87: {\displaystyle c=\sum _{i=1}^{n}z_{i}c_{i}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2640e32b5b59549c853a665c3a19562ee12705fe)
The _c_-parameter of the individual fluid components in a petroleum gas and oil can be estimated by the correlation

![Image 88: {\displaystyle c_{i}\approx 0.40768\ {\frac {RT_{ci}}{P_{ci}}}\left(0.29441-Z_{{\text{RA}},i}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8e316dc60b0a66e0308dcbf66c174389a9d767dd)
where the Rackett compressibility factor ![Image 89: {\displaystyle Z_{{\text{RA}},i}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b68f3de61a50ba31b649ab8e81cc62fd9d376992) can be estimated by

![Image 90: {\displaystyle Z_{{\text{RA}},i}\approx 0.29056-0.08775\ \omega _{i}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8d9929314a9edd6a868b0e23be925b64a885d270)
A nice feature with the volume translation method of Peneloux et al. (1982) is that it does not affect the vapor–liquid equilibrium calculations.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Knudsen1992-9) This method of volume translation can also be applied to other cubic EOSs if the _c_-parameter correlation is adjusted to match the selected EOS.

Peng–Robinson equation of state
-------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Peng–Robinson equation of state")]

The Peng–Robinson equation of state (PR EOS) was developed in 1976 at The [University of Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Alberta "University of Alberta") by [Ding-Yu Peng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ding_Yu_Peng "Ding Yu Peng") and Donald Robinson in order to satisfy the following goals:[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-10)

1.   The parameters should be expressible in terms of the [critical properties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_properties "Critical properties") and the [acentric factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acentric_factor "Acentric factor").
2.   The model should provide reasonable accuracy near the critical point, particularly for calculations of the [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor") and liquid density.
3.   The mixing rules should not employ more than a single binary interaction parameter, which should be independent of temperature, pressure, and composition.
4.   The equation should be applicable to all calculations of all fluid properties in natural gas processes.

The equation is given as follows:

![Image 91: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a\,\alpha }{V_{\text{m}}^{2}+2bV_{\text{m}}-b^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/63f7edfd939dff6d143889216a2b8c409bb5a82c)

![Image 92: {\displaystyle a=\Omega _{a}{\frac {R^{2}\,T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{p_{\text{c}}}};\Omega _{a}={\frac {8+40\eta _{c}}{49-37\eta _{c}}}\approx 0.45724}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a9f9f43ab29679ee253462b5c5e9e7c03cf434d1)

![Image 93: {\displaystyle b=\Omega _{b}{\frac {R\,T_{\text{c}}}{p_{\text{c}}}};\Omega _{b}={\frac {\eta _{c}}{3+\eta _{c}}}\approx 0.07780}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/55a9cc305212d453807cf98870b6ee8d8384a0c9)

![Image 94: {\displaystyle \eta _{c}=[1+(4-{\sqrt {8}})^{1/3}+(4+{\sqrt {8}})^{1/3}]^{-1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cb605906fededbb760c6b0ba5f525e55db16962b)

![Image 95: {\displaystyle \alpha =\left(1+\kappa \left(1-{\sqrt {T_{\text{r}}}}\right)\right)^{2};T_{\text{r}}={\frac {T}{T_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8f1d62b5475f617a2f4fd41d5cd85ac1632ec83)

![Image 96: {\displaystyle \kappa \approx 0.37464+1.54226\omega -0.26992\omega ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b04e2590ea9eb7e37b342c59a3a49551ab2db5e8)

In polynomial form:

![Image 97: {\displaystyle A={\frac {\alpha ap}{R^{2}\,T^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7d559525f881adf9cbdfbb49244e492f1664945e)![Image 98: {\displaystyle B={\frac {bp}{RT}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4a30c5aabdea0a30e093f28b20101f37ae49d91e)![Image 99: {\displaystyle Z^{3}-(1-B)Z^{2}+\left(A-2B-3B^{2}\right)Z-\left(AB-B^{2}-B^{3}\right)=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1ced617f3c6cab58bcdb6dd5c162ad8791f0fbc8)
For the most part the Peng–Robinson equation exhibits performance similar to the Soave equation, although it is generally superior in predicting the liquid densities of many materials, especially nonpolar ones.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-11) Detailed performance of the original Peng-Robinson equation has been reported for density, thermal properties, and phase equilibria.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PGL6ed-12) Briefly, the original form exhibits deviations in vapor pressure and phase equilibria that are roughly three times as large as the updated implementations. The [departure functions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Departure_function "Departure function") of the Peng–Robinson equation are given on a separate article.

The analytic values of its characteristic constants are:

![Image 100: {\displaystyle Z_{\text{c}}={\frac {1}{32}}\left(11-2{\sqrt {7}}\sinh \left({\frac {1}{3}}\operatorname {arsinh} \left({\frac {13}{7{\sqrt {7}}}}\right)\right)\right)\approx 0.307401}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d1dec04d14aaa43e595dc58882cdc675e165bddc)![Image 101: {\displaystyle b'={\frac {b}{V_{{\text{m}},{\text{c}}}}}={\frac {1}{3}}\left({\sqrt {8}}\sinh \left({\frac {1}{3}}\operatorname {arsinh} \left({\sqrt {8}}\right)\right)-1\right)\approx 0.253077\approx {\frac {0.07780}{Z_{\text{c}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cba75f1a24c4bb66aec7955cad739fae95560aa5)![Image 102: {\displaystyle {\frac {P_{\text{c}}V_{{\text{m}},{\text{c}}}^{2}}{a\,b'}}={\frac {3}{8}}\left(1+\cosh \left({\frac {1}{3}}\operatorname {arcosh} (3)\right)\right)\approx 0.816619\approx {\frac {Z_{\text{c}}^{2}}{0.45724\,b'}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7f22f0a84b24e3ea0b792c4dc9f600edc3673bdf)

Peng–Robinson–Stryjek–Vera equations of state
---------------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Peng–Robinson–Stryjek–Vera equations of state")]

A modification to the attraction term in the Peng–Robinson equation of state published by Stryjek and Vera in 1986 (PRSV) significantly improved the model's accuracy by introducing an adjustable pure component parameter and by modifying the polynomial fit of the acentric factor.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PRSV1-13)

The modification is:

![Image 103: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\kappa &=\kappa _{0}+\kappa _{1}\left(1+T_{\text{r}}^{\frac {1}{2}}\right)\left(0.7-T_{\text{r}}\right)\\\kappa _{0}&=0.378893+1.4897153\,\omega -0.17131848\,\omega ^{2}+0.0196554\,\omega ^{3}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/72eed1b3f3a5a9c954ab5f09f80003d20a0e59af)
where ![Image 104: {\displaystyle \kappa _{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78471d428eed0c2e016ad82fb2f30af4cedc86eb) is an adjustable pure component parameter. Stryjek and Vera published pure component parameters for many compounds of industrial interest in their original journal article. At reduced temperatures above 0.7, they recommend to set ![Image 105: {\displaystyle \kappa _{1}=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bc1257de71f902c543dc8cd241da83dfeb6a6c95) and simply use ![Image 106: {\displaystyle \kappa =\kappa _{0}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/53641c3128b38199e587631af4f240109aceead6). For alcohols and water the value of ![Image 107: {\displaystyle \kappa _{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78471d428eed0c2e016ad82fb2f30af4cedc86eb) may be used up to the critical temperature and set to zero at higher temperatures.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PRSV1-13)

A subsequent modification published in 1986 (PRSV2) further improved the model's accuracy by introducing two additional pure component parameters to the previous attraction term modification.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PRSV2-14)

The modification is:

![Image 108: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\kappa &=\kappa _{0}+\left[\kappa _{1}+\kappa _{2}\left(\kappa _{3}-T_{\text{r}}\right)\left(1-T_{\text{r}}^{\frac {1}{2}}\right)\right]\left(1+T_{\text{r}}^{\frac {1}{2}}\right)\left(0.7-T_{\text{r}}\right)\\\kappa _{0}&=0.378893+1.4897153\,\omega -0.17131848\,\omega ^{2}+0.0196554\,\omega ^{3}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/74e34a06349fb48148fb94dd62d62c04f07c962f)
where ![Image 109: {\displaystyle \kappa _{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78471d428eed0c2e016ad82fb2f30af4cedc86eb), ![Image 110: {\displaystyle \kappa _{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c55c9239a3520d5ef55ae207eaebb7bb518d81f3), and ![Image 111: {\displaystyle \kappa _{3}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8cca227029b593f32edbc7bf936766f8c3291a53) are adjustable pure component parameters.

PRSV2 is particularly advantageous for [VLE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium") calculations. While PRSV1 does offer an advantage over the Peng–Robinson model for describing thermodynamic behavior, it is still not accurate enough, in general, for phase equilibrium calculations.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PRSV1-13) The highly non-linear behavior of phase-equilibrium calculation methods tends to amplify what would otherwise be acceptably small errors. It is therefore recommended that PRSV2 be used for equilibrium calculations when applying these models to a design. However, once the equilibrium state has been determined, the phase specific thermodynamic values at equilibrium may be determined by one of several simpler models with a reasonable degree of accuracy.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PRSV2-14)

One thing to note is that in the PRSV equation, the parameter fit is done in a particular temperature range which is usually below the critical temperature. Above the critical temperature, the PRSV alpha function tends to diverge and become arbitrarily large instead of tending towards 0. Because of this, alternate equations for alpha should be employed above the critical point. This is especially important for systems containing hydrogen which is often found at temperatures far above its critical point. Several alternate formulations have been proposed. Some well known ones are by Twu et al.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] and by Mathias and Copeman.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] An extensive treatment of over 1700 compounds using the Twu method has been reported by Jaubert and coworkers.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-15) Detailed performance of the updated Peng-Robinson equation by Jaubert and coworkers has been reported for density, thermal properties, and phase equilibria.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PGL6ed-12) Briefly, the updated form exhibits deviations in vapor pressure and phase equilibria that are roughly a third as large as the original implementation.

Peng–Robinson–Babalola-Susu equation of state (PRBS)
----------------------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Peng–Robinson–Babalola-Susu equation of state (PRBS)")]

Babalola and Susu [[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-16) modified the Peng–Robinson Equation of state as:

![Image 112: {\displaystyle P=\left({\frac {RT}{V_{\mathrm {m} }-b}}\right)-\left[{\frac {(a_{1}P+a_{2})\alpha }{V_{\mathrm {m} }(V_{\mathrm {m} }+b)+b(V_{\mathrm {m} }-b)}}\right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e287dee584e58d29d2af02641857768e07e968bd)

The attractive force parameter ‘a’ was considered to be a constant with respect to pressure in the Peng–Robinson equation of state. The modification, in which parameter ‘a’ was treated as a variable with respect to pressure for multicomponent multi-phase high density reservoir systems was to improve accuracy in the prediction of properties of complex reservoir fluids for PVT modeling.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-IJoT_Model-17) The variation was represented with a linear equation where a 1 and a 2 were the slope and the intercept respectively of the straight line obtained when values of parameter ‘a’ are plotted against pressure.

This modification increases the accuracy of the Peng–Robinson equation of state for heavier fluids particularly at high pressure ranges (>30MPa) and eliminates the need for tuning the original Peng–Robinson equation of state. Tunning was captured inherently during the modification of the Peng-Robinson Equation.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Pet_Sc_Deterioration-18)

The Peng-Robinson-Babalola-Susu (PRBS) Equation of State (EoS) was developed in 2005 and for about two decades now has been applied to numerous reservoir field data at varied temperature (T) and pressure (P) conditions and shown to rank among the few promising EoS for accurate prediction of reservoir fluid properties especially for more challenging ultra-deep reservoirs at High-Temperature High-Pressure (HTHP) conditions. These works have been published in reputable journals.

While the widely used Peng-Robinson (PR) EoS of 1976 can predict fluid properties of conventional reservoirs with good accuracy up to pressures of about 27 MPa (4,000 psi) but fail with pressure increase, the new Peng-Robinson-Babalola-Susu (PRBS) EoS can accurately model PVT behavior of ultra-deep reservoir complex fluid systems at very high pressures of up to 120 MPa (17,500 psi).

Elliott–Suresh–Donohue equation of state
----------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Elliott–Suresh–Donohue equation of state")]

The Elliott–Suresh–Donohue (ESD) equation of state was proposed in 1990.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ESD-19) The equation corrects the inaccurate van der Waals repulsive term that is also applied in the Peng–Robinson EOS. The attractive term includes a contribution that relates to the second virial coefficient of square-well spheres, and also shares some features of the Twu temperature dependence. The EOS accounts for the effect of the shape of any molecule and can be directly extended to polymers with molecular parameters characterized in terms of solubility parameter and liquid volume instead of using critical properties (as shown here).[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-20) The EOS itself was developed through comparisons with computer simulations and should capture the essential physics of size, shape, and hydrogen bonding as inferred from straight chain molecules (like _n_-alkanes).

![Image 113: {\displaystyle {\frac {pV_{\text{m}}}{RT}}=Z=1+Z^{\rm {rep}}+Z^{\rm {att}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9f5737db7769cefdf52131243d2cdf50b6cf550e)
where:

![Image 114: {\displaystyle Z^{\rm {rep}}={\frac {4c\eta }{1-1.9\eta }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fdbdccc4b25f04707be25b86c3c384479e467cef)![Image 115: {\displaystyle Z^{\rm {att}}=-{\frac {z_{\text{m}}q\eta Y}{1+k_{1}\eta Y}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ab8a13c6770edb61bbb45456e4df8449d3b36a18)
and ![Image 116: {\displaystyle c}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/86a67b81c2de995bd608d5b2df50cd8cd7d92455) is a "shape factor", with ![Image 117: {\displaystyle c=1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e3467f9e219a5ea38a30da5c3a02c2c23f61a79) for spherical molecules.

For non-spherical molecules, the following relation between the shape factor and the acentric factor is suggested:

![Image 118: {\displaystyle c=1+3.535\omega +0.533\omega ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/feaa471e56986396ccae0bedf68f9efbfbd4b12e).
The reduced [number density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Number_density "Number density")![Image 119: {\displaystyle \eta }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e4d701857cf5fbec133eebaf94deadf722537f64) is defined as ![Image 120: {\displaystyle \eta =b\rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/88d6209a0b6127fc9e1fb544cbf33b139be9ad99), where

![Image 121: {\displaystyle b}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f11423fbb2e967f986e36804a8ae4271734917c3) is the characteristic size parameter [cm 3/mol], and![Image 122: {\displaystyle \rho ={\frac {1}{V_{\text{m}}}}=N/(N_{\text{A}}V)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c30d399de7c5dcf41627ab53e6c7b68e800f28e8) is the molar density [mol/cm 3].
The characteristic size parameter is related to ![Image 123: {\displaystyle c}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/86a67b81c2de995bd608d5b2df50cd8cd7d92455) through

![Image 124: {\displaystyle b={\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{P_{\text{c}}}}\Phi }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/985d2f5e1c96946a823981930a5f8d2411466fdb)
where

![Image 125: {\displaystyle \Phi ={\frac {Z_{\text{c}}^{2}}{2A_{q}}}{[-B_{q}+{\sqrt {B_{q}^{2}+4A_{q}C_{q}}}]}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8146bb6655f0ec3c914e3937571eb6f187433122)![Image 126: {\displaystyle 3Z_{\text{c}}=([(-0.173/{\sqrt {c}}+0.217)/{\sqrt {c}}-0.186]/{\sqrt {c}}+0.115)/{\sqrt {c}}+1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d3024df48f9e37b3d6c653a09733a11533d090e4)![Image 127: {\displaystyle A_{q}=[1.9(9.5q-k_{1})+4ck_{1}](4c-1.9)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/347df8ac562f767609d6d813dae39ec61cec1960)![Image 128: {\displaystyle B_{q}=1.9k_{1}Z_{\text{c}}+3A_{q}/(4c-1.9)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7d92c9f4edf3a213ef08e8588fc043a128a225ea)![Image 129: {\displaystyle C_{q}=(9.5q-k_{1})/Z_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7d662f375eb41a1cc4d6ade9396cd4a471464a8c)
The shape parameter ![Image 130: {\displaystyle q}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/06809d64fa7c817ffc7e323f85997f783dbdf71d) appearing in the attraction term and the term ![Image 131: {\displaystyle Y}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/961d67d6b454b4df2301ac571808a3538b3a6d3f) are given by

![Image 132: {\displaystyle q=1+k_{3}(c-1)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4fb5309731e2c527c4c7733d3e6adcbca3268c91) (and is hence also equal to 1 for spherical molecules).![Image 133: {\displaystyle Y=\exp \left({\frac {\epsilon }{kT}}\right)-k_{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cd72b0a2150bf757e74ac58ac1bd457d11e5cc92)
where ![Image 134: {\displaystyle \epsilon }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3837cad72483d97bcdde49c85d3b7b859fb3fd2) is the depth of the square-well potential and is given by

![Image 135: {\displaystyle Y_{\text{c}}=({\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{bP_{\text{c}}}})^{2}{\frac {Z_{\text{c}}^{3}}{A_{q}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e14351fb1a6e14c987e1265f3e126dfab322db95)![Image 136: {\displaystyle z_{\text{m}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b1675f6956595f6603f54c573736f5c05a33ede1), ![Image 137: {\displaystyle k_{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/376315fd4983f01dada5ec2f7bebc48455b14a66), ![Image 138: {\displaystyle k_{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c51b4ba57ee596d8435fc4ed76703ca3a2fc444a) and ![Image 139: {\displaystyle k_{3}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/40d32e1c66b85257bfd6ad8be93186742d71a804) are constants in the equation of state:![Image 140: {\displaystyle z_{\text{m}}=9.5}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e5abfc34f7d9f69d33b0bf6a09dedc5aa217f1be), ![Image 141: {\displaystyle k_{1}=1.7745}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d297819bed984a384fdecda72d467d789b6fad22), ![Image 142: {\displaystyle k_{2}=1.0617}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1ca01d3caf3458e7fe5d51e508bf3991377b5880), ![Image 143: {\displaystyle k_{3}=1.90476.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/51b7f6db11e28e78f9a3cc3bcd12fdfecff6a783)
The model can be extended to associating components and mixtures with non-associating components. Details are in the paper by J.R. Elliott, Jr. _et al._ (1990).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ESD-19)

Noting that ![Image 144: {\displaystyle 4(k_{3}-1)/k_{3}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5dd371755c3443c03f9e890a6684fea68e5ed9d3) = 1.900, ![Image 145: {\displaystyle Z^{\text{rep}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/34e7c0a31b1525d9b980d4eab3563ff64374068b) can be rewritten in the SAFT[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-22) form as:

![Image 146: {\displaystyle Z^{\rm {rep}}=4q\eta g-(q-1){\frac {\eta }{g}}{\frac {dg}{d\eta }}={\frac {4q\eta }{1-1.9\eta }}-{\frac {(q-1)1.9\eta }{1-1.9\eta }};g={\frac {1}{1-1.9\eta }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b3b772bd26d293acaa1795d3baab32b4a38faa)
If preferred, the ![Image 147: {\displaystyle q}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/06809d64fa7c817ffc7e323f85997f783dbdf71d) can be replaced by ![Image 148: {\displaystyle m}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0a07d98bb302f3856cbabc47b2b9016692e3f7bc) in SAFT notation and the ESD EOS can be written:

![Image 149: {\displaystyle Z=1+m({\frac {4\eta }{1-1.9\eta }}-{\frac {9.5Y\eta }{1+k_{1}Y\eta }})-{\frac {(m-1)1.9\eta }{1-1.9\eta }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8f087819272d7bc5f413716e68039163cdf78056)
In this form, SAFT's segmental perspective is evident and all the results of Michael Wertheim[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Wertheim1986a-23) are directly applicable and relatively succinct. In SAFT's segmental perspective, each molecule is conceived as comprising _m_ spherical segments floating in space with their own spherical interactions, but then corrected for bonding into a tangent sphere chain by the (_m_ − 1) term. When _m_ is not an integer, it is simply considered as an "effective" number of tangent sphere segments.

Solving the equations in Wertheim's theory can be complicated, but simplifications can make their implementation less daunting. Briefly, a few extra steps are needed to compute ![Image 150: {\displaystyle Z^{\rm {assoc}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/21dd08f9e52a32d5cf992a631c25469537c3f346)given density and temperature. For example, when the number of hydrogen bonding donors is equal to the number of acceptors, the ESD equation becomes:

![Image 151: {\displaystyle {\frac {pV_{\text{m}}}{RT}}=Z=1+Z^{\rm {rep}}+Z^{\rm {att}}+Z^{\rm {assoc}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/41466a8476c36ad6de5ed00a887d831037f75d8b)
where:

![Image 152: {\displaystyle Z^{\rm {assoc}}=-gN^{\text{AD}}(1-X^{\text{AD}});X^{\text{AD}}=2/[1+{\sqrt {1+4N^{\text{AD}}\alpha ^{\text{AD}}}}];\alpha ^{\text{AD}}=\rho N_{\text{A}}K^{\text{AD}}[\exp {(\epsilon ^{\text{AD}}/kT)-1]}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a6b815b317c6b9664bfadf3382d8465388f3702b)
![Image 153: {\displaystyle N_{\text{A}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/037f8d054f445451d8fee1b440cddba989e66ea1) is the Avogadro constant, ![Image 154: {\displaystyle K^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dd7811993ae126c2e3db8b51c907c17cbc82cba7) and ![Image 155: {\displaystyle \epsilon ^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/74a6c489c05fd8e15311856b00bdaea2a107d911) are stored input parameters representing the volume and energy of hydrogen bonding. Typically, ![Image 156: {\displaystyle K^{\text{AD}}=\mathrm {0.001\ nm^{3}} }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/35ea8914eb186b253a56c4d9d7955463590de3a7) and ![Image 157: {\displaystyle \epsilon ^{\text{AD}}/k_{\text{B}}=\mathrm {2000\ K} }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/16c10c962de820dbf8735403cf910a4aaddde90c) are stored. ![Image 158: {\displaystyle N^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e8f16acdf107ca17d73cc1cf666f87562318920) is the number of acceptors (equal to number of donors for this example). For example, ![Image 159: {\displaystyle N^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e8f16acdf107ca17d73cc1cf666f87562318920) = 1 for alcohols like methanol and ethanol. ![Image 160: {\displaystyle N^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e8f16acdf107ca17d73cc1cf666f87562318920) = 2 for water. ![Image 161: {\displaystyle N^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e8f16acdf107ca17d73cc1cf666f87562318920) = degree of polymerization for polyvinylphenol. So you use the density and temperature to calculate ![Image 162: {\displaystyle \alpha ^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f58d00a035a93621b9bbe85f4061f56000f2d501) then use ![Image 163: {\displaystyle \alpha ^{\text{AD}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f58d00a035a93621b9bbe85f4061f56000f2d501) to calculate the other quantities. Technically, the ESD equation is no longer cubic when the association term is included, but no artifacts are introduced so there are only three roots in density. The extension to efficiently treat any number of electron acceptors (acids) and donors (bases), including mixtures of self-associating, cross-associating, and non-associating compounds, has been presented here.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-24)[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-25) Detailed performance of the ESD equation has been reported for density, thermal properties, and phase equilibria.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-PGL6ed-12) Briefly, the ESD equation exhibits deviations in vapor pressure and vapor-liquid equilibria that are roughly twice as large as the Peng-Robinson form as updated by Jaubert and coworkers, but deviations in liquid-liquid equilibria are roughly 40% smaller.

Cubic-plus-association
----------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Cubic-plus-association")]

The cubic-plus-association (CPA) equation of state combines the Soave–Redlich–Kwong equation with the association term from SAFT[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-22) based on Chapman's extensions and simplifications of a theory of associating molecules due to Michael Wertheim.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Wertheim1986a-23) The development of the equation began in 1995 as a research project that was funded by Shell, and published in 1996.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:0-26)[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-27)

![Image 164: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{(V_{\mathrm {m} }-b)}}-{\frac {a}{V_{\mathrm {m} }(V_{\mathrm {m} }+b)}}+{\frac {RT}{V_{\mathrm {m} }}}\rho \sum _{A}\left[{\frac {1}{X^{\text{A}}}}-{\frac {1}{2}}\right]{\frac {\partial X^{\text{A}}}{\partial \rho }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a31bae0e4b32e94eccc5105e2bb4351a3f676aa8)
In the association term ![Image 165: {\displaystyle X^{\text{A}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7d729ea4140b8fffbb61e50cfda460fd75fdbb06) is the mole fraction of molecules not bonded at site A.

Cubic-plus-chain equation of state
----------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cubic_equations_of_state&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Cubic-plus-chain equation of state")]

The cubic-plus-chain (CPC)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:2-28)[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-29)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:3-30) equation of state hybridizes the classical cubic equation of state with the SAFT chain term.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-22) The addition of the chain term allows the model to be capable of capturing the physics of both short-chain and long-chain non-associating components ranging from alkanes to polymers. The CPC monomer term is not restricted to one classical cubic EOS form, instead many forms can be used within the same framework. The cubic-plus-chain (CPC) equation of state is written in terms of the reduced residual Helmholtz energy (![Image 166: {\displaystyle F^{\mathrm {CPC} }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/292b12766d1c535f4b8f21b1173578e9509f19de)) as:

![Image 167: {\displaystyle F^{\mathrm {CPC} }={\frac {A^{\mathrm {R} }(T,V,{\textbf {n}})}{RT}}=m(F^{\mathrm {rep} }+F^{\mathrm {att} })+F^{\mathrm {chain} }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2831aa05b59ce6c0e8e376a528c75b3a3342da04)

where ![Image 168: {\displaystyle A^{\mathrm {R} }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c0ae1cd7d76579f229bcdd31278208118a297833) is the residual Helmholtz energy, ![Image 169: {\displaystyle m}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0a07d98bb302f3856cbabc47b2b9016692e3f7bc) is the chain length, "rep" and "att" are the monomer repulsive and attractive contributions of the cubic equation of state, respectively. The "chain" term accounts for the monomer beads bonding contribution from SAFT equation of state. Using Redlich−Kwong (RK) for the monomer term, CPC can be written as:

![Image 170: {\displaystyle p={\frac {nRT}{V}}{\Biggl (}1+{\frac {{\bar {m}}^{2}B}{V-{\bar {m}}B}}{\Biggr )}-{\frac {{\bar {m}}^{2}A}{V(V+{\bar {m}}B)}}-{\frac {nRT}{V}}\left[\sum _{i}n_{i}(m_{i}-1)\beta {\frac {g'(\beta )}{g(\beta )}}\right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5e89b0fa881430f6987a2f6d1791a49cf8973b30)

where A is the molecular interaction energy parameter, B is the co-volume parameter, ![Image 171: {\displaystyle {\bar {m}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/69328c84c2cc565cd6aade2135b40be6f520f5f1) is the mole-average chain length, _g(β)_ is the radial distribution function (RDF) evaluated at contact, and _β_ is the reduced volume.

The CPC model combines the simplicity and speed compared to other complex models used to model polymers. Sisco et al.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:2-28)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-:3-30) applied the CPC equation of state to model different well-defined and polymer mixtures. They analyzed different factors including elevated pressure, temperature, solvent types, polydispersity, etc. The CPC model proved to be capable of modeling different systems by testing the results with experimental data.

Alajmi et al.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state#cite_note-31) incorporate the short-range soft repulsion to the CPC framework to enhance vapor pressure and liquid density predictions. They provided a database for more than 50 components from different chemical families, including _n_-alkanes, alkenes, branched alkanes, cycloalkanes, benzene derivatives, gases, etc. This CPC version uses a temperature-dependent co-volume parameter based on perturbation theory to describe short-range soft repulsion between molecules.
