Title: Equation of state

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state

Published Time: 2001-07-27T06:18:07Z

Markdown Content:
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

In [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics") and [chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry"), an **equation of state** is a [thermodynamic equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_equations "Thermodynamic equations") relating [state variables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_variable "State variable"), which describe the state of matter under a given set of physical conditions, such as [pressure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure "Pressure"), [volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volume_(thermodynamics) "Volume (thermodynamics)"), [temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature "Temperature"), or [internal energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_energy "Internal energy").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Perrot-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-2) Most modern equations of state are formulated in the [Helmholtz free energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy "Helmholtz free energy"). Equations of state are useful in describing the properties of pure substances and mixtures in liquids, gases, and [solid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solid "Solid") states as well as the state of matter in the interior of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star "Star").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-3) Though there are many equations of state, none accurately predicts properties of substances under all conditions. The quest for a universal equation of state has spanned three centuries.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-4)

At present, there is no single equation of state that accurately predicts the properties of all substances under all conditions. An example of an equation of state correlates densities of gases and liquids to temperatures and pressures, known as the [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law"), which is roughly accurate for weakly polar gases at low pressures and moderate temperatures. This equation becomes increasingly inaccurate at higher pressures and lower temperatures, and fails to predict condensation from a gas to a liquid.

The general form of an equation of state may be written as ![Image 1: {\displaystyle f(p,V,T)=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0f34ad3ace8b4b84ff98f2ef5d777b36610f3ade)

where ![Image 2: {\displaystyle p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36) is the pressure, ![Image 3: {\displaystyle V}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/af0f6064540e84211d0ffe4dac72098adfa52845) the volume, and ![Image 4: {\displaystyle T}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0) the temperature of the system. Yet also other variables may be used in that form. It is directly related to [Gibbs phase rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_rule "Phase rule"), that is, the number of independent variables depends on the number of substances and phases in the system.

An equation used to model this relationship is called an equation of state. In most cases this model will comprise some empirical parameters that are usually adjusted to measurement data. Equations of state can also describe solids, including the transition of solids from one crystalline state to another. Equations of state are also used for the modeling of the state of matter in the interior of stars, including [neutron stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutron_star "Neutron star"), dense matter ([quark–gluon plasmas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quark%E2%80%93gluon_plasma "Quark–gluon plasma")) and radiation fields. A related concept is the [perfect fluid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_fluid "Perfect fluid")[equation of state used in cosmology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state_(cosmology) "Equation of state (cosmology)").

Equations of state are applied in many fields such as [process engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_engineering "Process engineering") and petroleum industry as well as pharmaceutical industry.

Any consistent set of units may be used, although [SI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_System_of_Units "International System of Units") units are preferred. [Absolute temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_temperature "Thermodynamic temperature") refers to the use of the [Kelvin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelvin "Kelvin") (K), with zero being absolute zero.

Historical background
---------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Historical background")]

Equations of state essentially began three centuries ago with the history of the [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law"):[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-5)

![Image 5: {\displaystyle pV=nRT}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/57c364f7f0b47178cfd35c3bbaf6dcb22a98cf44)

[Boyle's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boyle%27s_law "Boyle's law") was one of the earliest formulation of an equation of state. In 1662, the Irish physicist and chemist [Robert Boyle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Boyle "Robert Boyle") performed a series of experiments employing a J-shaped glass tube, which was sealed on one end. [Mercury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercury_(element) "Mercury (element)") was added to the tube, trapping a fixed quantity of air in the short, sealed end of the tube. Then the volume of gas was measured as additional mercury was added to the tube. The pressure of the gas could be determined by the difference between the mercury level in the short end of the tube and that in the long, open end. Through these experiments, Boyle noted that the gas volume varied inversely with the pressure. In mathematical form, this can be stated as:![Image 6: {\displaystyle pV=\mathrm {constant} .}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3ad5a6d9e48267958f978e1b0dd2ef1445b4b784)The above relationship has also been attributed to [Edme Mariotte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edme_Mariotte "Edme Mariotte") and is sometimes referred to as Mariotte's law. However, Mariotte's work was not published until 1676.

In 1787 the French physicist [Jacques Charles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Charles "Jacques Charles") found that oxygen, nitrogen, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and air expand to roughly the same extent over the same 80-kelvin interval. This is known today as [Charles's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles%27s_law "Charles's law"). Later, in 1802, [Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Louis_Gay-Lussac "Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac") published results of similar experiments, indicating a linear relationship between volume and temperature:![Image 7: {\displaystyle {\frac {V_{1}}{T_{1}}}={\frac {V_{2}}{T_{2}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/86e0ec7f280021fca44ede90829fd4ce78f38436)[Dalton's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalton%27s_law "Dalton's law") (1801) of partial pressure states that the pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the pressures of all of the constituent gases alone.

Mathematically, this can be represented for ![Image 8: {\displaystyle n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a601995d55609f2d9f5e233e36fbe9ea26011b3b) species as:![Image 9: {\displaystyle p_{\text{total}}=p_{1}+p_{2}+\cdots +p_{n}=\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9399f17b153831248a37a40703e66cc959b60a36)In 1834, [Émile Clapeyron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Clapeyron "Émile Clapeyron") combined Boyle's law and Charles' law into the first statement of the _[ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal\_gas\_law "Ideal gas law")_. Initially, the law was formulated as _pV m_ = _R_(_T C_ + 267) (with temperature expressed in degrees Celsius), where _R_ is the [gas constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_constant "Gas constant"). However, later work revealed that the number should actually be closer to 273.2, and then the Celsius scale was defined with ![Image 10: {\displaystyle 0~^{\circ }\mathrm {C} =273.15~\mathrm {K} }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ebf84423865eba32404d3948b141e137ebaf06ba), giving:![Image 11: {\displaystyle pV_{m}=R\left(T_{C}+273.15\ {}^{\circ }{\text{C}}\right).}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e707dd5ca5d157a8f43863218f88cbe15c510c20)In 1873, [J. D. van der Waals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._D._van_der_Waals "J. D. van der Waals") introduced the first [equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation") derived by the assumption of a finite volume occupied by the constituent molecules.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-van_der_Waals-6) His new formula revolutionized the study of equations of state, and was the starting point of [cubic equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state "Cubic equations of state"), which most famously continued via the [Redlich–Kwong equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state "Redlich–Kwong equation of state")[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:1-7) and the [Soave modification of Redlich-Kwong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#Soave_modification_of_Redlich-Kwong).[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Soave_modification_of_Redlich-Kwong-8)

The van der Waals equation of state can be written as

![Image 12: {\displaystyle \left(P+a{\frac {1}{V_{m}^{2}}}\right)(V_{m}-b)=RT}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/50da03f6af49f00a43c1c6a09b56720ca7b965c9) where ![Image 13: {\displaystyle a}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffd2487510aa438433a2579450ab2b3d557e5edc) is a parameter describing the attractive energy between particles and ![Image 14: {\displaystyle b}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f11423fbb2e967f986e36804a8ae4271734917c3) is a parameter describing the volume of the particles.

### Classical ideal gas law

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Classical ideal gas law")]

The classical [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law") may be written ![Image 15: {\displaystyle pV=nRT.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/54cca221b78efee9c48265b496d5845f5bd8ee59)

In the form shown above, the equation of state is thus ![Image 16: {\displaystyle f(p,V,T)=pV-nRT=0.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dd15cd8519f689932ee5ee5e1dc742c5a92667e8)

If the [calorically perfect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_gas "Perfect gas") gas approximation is used, then the ideal gas law may also be expressed as follows ![Image 17: {\displaystyle p=\rho (\gamma -1)e}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a5d5de537aa6696e1faf0214d4c2a0374824699f) where ![Image 18: {\displaystyle \rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f7d439671d1289b6a816e6af7a304be40608d64) is the [number density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Number_density "Number density") of the gas (number of atoms/molecules per unit volume), ![Image 19: {\displaystyle \gamma =C_{p}/C_{v}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/54a4d62c8c5abcb9be36a572f789822f27fafc8c) is the (constant) adiabatic index ([ratio of specific heats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_capacity_ratio "Heat capacity ratio")), ![Image 20: {\displaystyle e=C_{v}T}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/545752b50cd5343b602a55f4791800703ef96511) is the internal energy per unit mass (the "specific internal energy"), ![Image 21: {\displaystyle C_{v}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4e351d30ded09e7d285c21e836f116e14ad5ae28) is the specific heat capacity at constant volume, and ![Image 22: {\displaystyle C_{p}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6bc37470431fbf62081b69ba870ad3f855178361) is the specific heat capacity at constant pressure.

### Quantum ideal gas law

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Quantum ideal gas law")]

Since for atomic and molecular gases, the classical ideal gas law is well suited in most cases, let us describe the equation of state for elementary particles with mass ![Image 23: {\displaystyle m}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0a07d98bb302f3856cbabc47b2b9016692e3f7bc) and spin ![Image 24: {\displaystyle s}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/01d131dfd7673938b947072a13a9744fe997e632) that takes into account quantum effects. In the following, the upper sign will always correspond to [Fermi–Dirac statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi%E2%80%93Dirac_statistics "Fermi–Dirac statistics") and the lower sign to [Bose–Einstein statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_statistics "Bose–Einstein statistics"). The equation of state of such gases with ![Image 25: {\displaystyle N}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f5e3890c981ae85503089652feb48b191b57aae3) particles occupying a volume ![Image 26: {\displaystyle V}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/af0f6064540e84211d0ffe4dac72098adfa52845) with temperature ![Image 27: {\displaystyle T}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0) and pressure ![Image 28: {\displaystyle p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36) is given by[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-9)

![Image 29: {\displaystyle p={\frac {(2s+1){\sqrt {2m^{3}k_{\text{B}}^{5}T^{5}}}}{3\pi ^{2}\hbar ^{3}}}\int _{0}^{\infty }{\frac {z^{3/2}\,\mathrm {d} z}{e^{z-\mu /(k_{\text{B}}T)}\pm 1}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e4710852c9e7e026fbe8f046c7ca6bba9fd0e7a2) where ![Image 30: {\displaystyle k_{\text{B}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9582c7c795d2def2c061f0dfa3a6f0fb3dd2de44) is the [Boltzmann constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boltzmann_constant "Boltzmann constant") and ![Image 31: {\displaystyle \mu (T,N/V)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9da0ca2bcc869ffc841fa83bd62891e3ec647c05) the [chemical potential](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_potential "Chemical potential") is given by the following implicit function ![Image 32: {\displaystyle {\frac {N}{V}}={\frac {(2s+1)(mk_{\text{B}}T)^{3/2}}{{\sqrt {2}}\pi ^{2}\hbar ^{3}}}\int _{0}^{\infty }{\frac {z^{1/2}\,\mathrm {d} z}{e^{z-\mu /(k_{\text{B}}T)}\pm 1}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4fdc2a1013f2b459b2f3e28f0d063cbe93035989)

In the limiting case where ![Image 33: {\displaystyle e^{\mu /(k_{\text{B}}T)}\ll 1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7062463569a449b7e00778245ce935d12ee1fb8d), this equation of state will reduce to that of the classical ideal gas. It can be shown that the above equation of state in the limit ![Image 34: {\displaystyle e^{\mu /(k_{\text{B}}T)}\ll 1}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7062463569a449b7e00778245ce935d12ee1fb8d) reduces to

![Image 35: {\displaystyle pV=Nk_{\text{B}}T\left[1\pm {\frac {\pi ^{3/2}}{2(2s+1)}}{\frac {N\hbar ^{3}}{V(mk_{\text{B}}T)^{3/2}}}+\cdots \right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/09dfcf680791282a6c80d76f904cfccd3192ca94)

With a fixed number density ![Image 36: {\displaystyle N/V}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/eaa155f67e3e587c18df95a5afefbeb5201bd715), decreasing the temperature causes in [Fermi gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_gas "Fermi gas"), an increase in the value for pressure from its classical value implying an effective repulsion between particles (this is an apparent repulsion due to quantum exchange effects not because of actual interactions between particles since in ideal gas, interactional forces are neglected) and in [Bose gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose_gas "Bose gas"), a decrease in pressure from its classical value implying an effective attraction. The quantum nature of this equation is in it dependence on s and **ħ**.

Cubic equations of state
------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Cubic equations of state")]

[Cubic equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state "Cubic equations of state") are called such because they can be rewritten as a [cubic function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_function "Cubic function") of ![Image 37: {\displaystyle V_{m}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/40836783b20c374654ab03ddd6b01586ad9b4fb8). Cubic equations of state originated from the van der Waals equation of state. Hence, all cubic equations of state can be considered 'modified van der Waals equation of state'. There is a very large number of such cubic equations of state. For process engineering, cubic equations of state are today still highly relevant, e.g. the Peng Robinson equation of state or the Soave Redlich Kwong equation of state.

Virial equations of state
-------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Virial equations of state")]

### Virial equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Virial equation of state")]

![Image 38: {\displaystyle {\frac {pV_{m}}{RT}}=A+{\frac {B}{V_{m}}}+{\frac {C}{V_{m}^{2}}}+{\frac {D}{V_{m}^{3}}}+\cdots }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3146fd8275bfb1ef70bd0946a275fef7c3e6925)

Although usually not the most convenient equation of state, the virial equation is important because it can be derived directly from [statistical mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics "Statistical mechanics"). This equation is also called the [Kamerlingh Onnes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heike_Kamerlingh_Onnes "Heike Kamerlingh Onnes") equation. If appropriate assumptions are made about the mathematical form of intermolecular forces, theoretical expressions can be developed for each of the [coefficients](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_coefficient "Virial coefficient"). _A_ is the first virial coefficient, which has a constant value of 1 and makes the statement that when volume is large, all fluids behave like ideal gases. The second virial coefficient _B_ corresponds to interactions between pairs of molecules, _C_ to triplets, and so on. Accuracy can be increased indefinitely by considering higher order terms. The coefficients _B_, _C_, _D_, etc. are functions of temperature only.

### The BWR equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: The BWR equation of state")]

![Image 39: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}p=\rho RT&+\left(B_{0}RT-A_{0}-{\frac {C_{0}}{T^{2}}}+{\frac {D_{0}}{T^{3}}}-{\frac {E_{0}}{T^{4}}}\right)\rho ^{2}+\left(bRT-a-{\frac {d}{T}}\right)\rho ^{3}\\[2pt]&+\alpha \left(a+{\frac {d}{T}}\right)\rho ^{6}+{\frac {c\rho ^{3}}{T^{2}}}\left(1+\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)\exp \left(-\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7e65578173cdca5d39cf83ae810579d41d3856c4)

where

*   ![Image 40: {\displaystyle p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36) is pressure
*   ![Image 41: {\displaystyle \rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f7d439671d1289b6a816e6af7a304be40608d64) is molar density

Values of the various parameters can be found in reference materials.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-10) The BWR equation of state has also frequently been used for the modelling of the [Lennard-Jones fluid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lennard-Jones_fluid "Lennard-Jones fluid").[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Stephan_112772-11)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-12) There are several extensions and modifications of the classical BWR equation of state available.

The Benedict–Webb–Rubin–Starling[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-13) equation of state is a modified BWR equation of state and can be written as ![Image 42: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}p=\rho RT&+\left(B_{0}RT-A_{0}-{\frac {C_{0}}{T^{2}}}+{\frac {D_{0}}{T^{3}}}-{\frac {E_{0}}{T^{4}}}\right)\rho ^{2}\\[2pt]&+\left(bRT-a-{\frac {d}{T}}+{\frac {c}{T^{2}}}\right)\rho ^{3}+\alpha \left(a+{\frac {d}{T}}\right)\rho ^{6}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7f7eb42dc618e356beb8aa8228e5fbafab9e1568)

Note that in this virial equation, the fourth and fifth virial terms are zero. The second virial coefficient is monotonically decreasing as temperature is lowered. The third virial coefficient is monotonically increasing as temperature is lowered.

The Lee–Kesler equation of state is based on the corresponding states principle, and is a modification of the BWR equation of state.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-14)

![Image 43: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V}}\left(1+{\frac {B}{V_{r}}}+{\frac {C}{V_{r}^{2}}}+{\frac {D}{V_{r}^{5}}}+{\frac {c_{4}}{T_{r}^{3}V_{r}^{2}}}\left(\beta +{\frac {\gamma }{V_{r}^{2}}}\right)\exp \left(-{\frac {\gamma }{V_{r}^{2}}}\right)\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ca75b2133f1b3cabe0be09f0bcfd60489a1bf1f5)

Physically based equations of state
-----------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Physically based equations of state")]

There is a large number of physically based equations of state available today.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-15)[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-16)[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-17)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-18)[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-19)[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-20)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-22) Most of those are formulated in the [Helmholtz free energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy "Helmholtz free energy") as a function of temperature, density (and for mixtures additionally the composition). The Helmholtz energy is formulated as a sum of multiple terms modelling different types of molecular interaction or molecular structures, e.g. the formation of chains or [dipolar interactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole-dipole "Dipole-dipole"). Hence, physically based equations of state model the effect of molecular size, attraction and shape as well as hydrogen bonding and polar interactions of fluids. In general, physically based equations of state give more accurate results than traditional cubic equations of state, especially for systems containing liquids or solids. Most physically based equations of state are built on monomer term describing the [Lennard-Jones fluid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lennard-Jones_potential "Lennard-Jones potential") or the [Mie fluid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mie_potential "Mie potential").

### Perturbation theory-based models

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Perturbation theory-based models")]

[Perturbation theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory "Perturbation theory") is frequently used for modelling dispersive interactions in an equation of state. There is a large number of perturbation theory based equations of state available today,[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-23)[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-24) e.g. for the classical Lennard-Jones fluid.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Stephan_112772-11)[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-25) The two most important theories used for these types of equations of state are the Barker-Henderson perturbation theory[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-26) and the Weeks–Chandler–Andersen perturbation theory.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-27)

### Statistical associating fluid theory (SAFT)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Statistical associating fluid theory (SAFT)")]

An important contribution for physically based equations of state is the [statistical associating fluid theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory "Statistical associating fluid theory") (SAFT) that contributes the [Helmholtz energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy "Helmholtz free energy") that describes the association (a.k.a. [hydrogen bonding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_bond "Hydrogen bond")) in fluids, which can also be applied for modelling chain formation (in the limit of infinite association strength). The SAFT equation of state was developed using [statistical mechanical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics "Statistical mechanics") methods (in particular the [perturbation theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory "Perturbation theory") of Wertheim[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-28)) to describe the interactions between molecules in a system.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-20)[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-29)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-30) The idea of a SAFT equation of state was first proposed by Chapman et al. in 1988 and 1989.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-20)[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-29)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-30) Many different versions of the SAFT models have been proposed, but all use the same chain and association terms derived by Chapman et al.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Chapman1988-29)[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1990-31)[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-32)

Multiparameter equations of state
---------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Multiparameter equations of state")]

Multiparameter equations of state are empirical equations of state that can be used to represent pure fluids with high accuracy. Multiparameter equations of state are empirical correlations of experimental data and are usually formulated in the Helmholtz free energy. The functional form of these models is in most parts not physically motivated. They can be usually applied in both liquid and gaseous states. Empirical multiparameter equations of state represent the Helmholtz energy of the fluid as the sum of ideal gas and residual terms. Both terms are explicit in temperature and density: ![Image 44: {\displaystyle {\frac {a(T,\rho )}{RT}}={\frac {a^{\mathrm {ideal\,gas} }(\tau ,\delta )+a^{\textrm {residual}}(\tau ,\delta )}{RT}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3e4b4b1a6fc3ddf88b02002d4f4a3759ae3d516f) with ![Image 45: {\displaystyle \tau ={\frac {T_{r}}{T}},\delta ={\frac {\rho }{\rho _{r}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e18523f341f5d3333f7d69565b54b31954377e99)

The reduced density ![Image 46: {\displaystyle \rho _{r}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/855a86723a619b331f46c8ef789bad7fef4bdc3b) and reduced temperature ![Image 47: {\displaystyle T_{r}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5d42a2f96162536ac26ef7cefedb159170597124) are in most cases the critical values for the pure fluid. Because integration of the multiparameter equations of state is not required and thermodynamic properties can be determined using classical thermodynamic relations, there are few restrictions as to the functional form of the ideal or residual terms.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:2-33)[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:3-34) Typical multiparameter equations of state use upwards of 50 fluid specific parameters, but are able to represent the fluid's properties with high accuracy. Multiparameter equations of state are available currently for about 50 of the most common industrial fluids including refrigerants. The IAPWS95 reference equation of state for water is also a multiparameter equations of state.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:4-35) Mixture models for multiparameter equations of state exist, as well. Yet, multiparameter equations of state applied to mixtures are known to exhibit artifacts at times.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-36)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-37)

One example of such an equation of state is the form proposed by Span and Wagner.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:2-33)

![Image 48: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a^{\mathrm {residual} }={}&\sum _{i=1}^{8}\sum _{j=-8}^{12}n_{i,j}\delta ^{i}\tau ^{j/8}+\sum _{i=1}^{5}\sum _{j=-8}^{24}n_{i,j}\delta ^{i}\tau ^{j/8}\exp \left(-\delta \right)\\&+\sum _{i=1}^{5}\sum _{j=16}^{56}n_{i,j}\delta ^{i}\tau ^{j/8}\exp \left(-\delta ^{2}\right)+\sum _{i=2}^{4}\sum _{j=24}^{38}n_{i,j}\delta ^{i}\tau ^{j/2}\exp \left(-\delta ^{3}\right)\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/734a5496d8c31d12cf7119e05f0564167aca7373)

This is a somewhat simpler form that is intended to be used more in technical applications.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:2-33) Equations of state that require a higher accuracy use a more complicated form with more terms.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:4-35)[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-:3-34)

List of further equations of state
----------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: List of further equations of state")]

### Stiffened equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Stiffened equation of state")]

When considering water under very high pressures, in situations such as [underwater nuclear explosions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_explosion "Underwater explosion"), [sonic shock lithotripsy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extracorporeal_shock_wave_lithotripsy "Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy"), and [sonoluminescence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonoluminescence "Sonoluminescence"), the stiffened equation of state[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-38) is often used:

![Image 49: {\displaystyle p=\rho (\gamma -1)e-\gamma p^{0}\,}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b1a3f6be05e9aca8e44038351b640dcc18240e10)

where ![Image 50: {\displaystyle e}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cd253103f0876afc68ebead27a5aa9867d927467) is the internal energy per unit mass, ![Image 51: {\displaystyle \gamma }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a223c880b0ce3da8f64ee33c4f0010beee400b1a) is an empirically determined constant typically taken to be about 6.1, and ![Image 52: {\displaystyle p^{0}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/92a2e2fda83d61a09cadf00ac7a1e4545d7584b0) is another constant, representing the molecular attraction between water molecules. The magnitude of the correction is about 2 gigapascals (20,000 atmospheres).

The equation is stated in this form because the speed of sound in water is given by ![Image 53: {\displaystyle c^{2}=\gamma \left(p+p^{0}\right)/\rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/aff48bd08a05a9ab66a9a1e86ed3ac619a2d72f7).

Thus water behaves as though it is an ideal gas that is _already_ under about 20,000 atmospheres (2 GPa) pressure, and explains why water is commonly assumed to be incompressible: when the external pressure changes from 1 atmosphere to 2 atmospheres (100 kPa to 200 kPa), the water behaves as an ideal gas would when changing from 20,001 to 20,002 atmospheres (2000.1 MPa to 2000.2 MPa).

This equation mispredicts the [specific heat capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specific_heat_capacity "Specific heat capacity") of water but few simple alternatives are available for severely nonisentropic processes such as strong shocks.

### Morse oscillator equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Morse oscillator equation of state")]

An equation of state of Morse oscillator has been derived,[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-39) and it has the following form:

![Image 54: {\displaystyle p=\Gamma _{1}\nu +\Gamma _{2}\nu ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/796137dad3901745823f7235f3b71ed6c97bc9bc)

Where ![Image 55: {\displaystyle \Gamma _{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/427e60078dcc86b35e6822c29368bd4a086ecb18) is the first order virial parameter and it depends on the temperature, ![Image 56: {\displaystyle \Gamma _{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c0c3af2863f650e8ffbc1fd37149f3c37c479116) is the second order virial parameter of Morse oscillator and it depends on the parameters of Morse oscillator in addition to the absolute temperature. ![Image 57: {\displaystyle \nu }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c15bbbb971240cf328aba572178f091684585468) is the fractional volume of the system.

### Ultrarelativistic equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Ultrarelativistic equation of state")]

An [ultrarelativistic fluid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultrarelativistic_fluid "Ultrarelativistic fluid") has equation of state ![Image 58: {\displaystyle p=\rho _{m}c_{s}^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/65c7d8cba974e260ed0cff2b621d3738cd24f4c4) where ![Image 59: {\displaystyle p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81eac1e205430d1f40810df36a0edffdc367af36) is the pressure, ![Image 60: {\displaystyle \rho _{m}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fb8e01f5f9a1ec7641573c415df8bfa942a42a78) is the mass density, and ![Image 61: {\displaystyle c_{s}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/75b83e050da28fa0d83e2aa786963805742ab756) is the [speed of sound](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speed_of_sound "Speed of sound").

### Ideal Bose equation of state

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Ideal Bose equation of state")]

The equation of state for an ideal [Bose gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose_gas "Bose gas") is

![Image 62: {\displaystyle pV_{m}=RT~{\frac {\operatorname {Li} _{\alpha +1}(z)}{\zeta (\alpha )}}\left({\frac {T}{T_{c}}}\right)^{\alpha }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/94eef6df08b4e06b2b13d355a2af3ddc2d3702f2)

where _α_ is an exponent specific to the system (e.g. in the absence of a potential field, α = 3/2), _z_ is exp(_μ_/_k_ B _T_) where _μ_ is the [chemical potential](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_potential "Chemical potential"), Li is the [polylogarithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polylogarithm "Polylogarithm"), ζ is the [Riemann zeta function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function "Riemann zeta function"), and _T_ _c_ is the critical temperature at which a [Bose–Einstein condensate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_condensate "Bose–Einstein condensate") begins to form.

### Jones–Wilkins–Lee equation of state for explosives (JWL equation)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Equation_of_state&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Jones–Wilkins–Lee equation of state for explosives (JWL equation)")]

The equation of state from Jones–Wilkins–Lee is used to describe the detonation products of explosives. ![Image 63: {\displaystyle p=A\left(1-{\frac {\omega }{R_{1}V}}\right)\exp(-R_{1}V)+B\left(1-{\frac {\omega }{R_{2}V}}\right)\exp \left(-R_{2}V\right)+{\frac {\omega e_{0}}{V}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/167d7a4f03a06f6ee149c16c2ce3f8659426a920)

The ratio ![Image 64: {\displaystyle V=\rho _{e}/\rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3c77056f1fbf1d91fbad74fbbf5b24b32a70a955) is defined by using ![Image 65: {\displaystyle \rho _{e}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d972eda14d3f9d5d046cd8a1c8ba3dcd0f09a84d), which is the density of the explosive (solid part) and ![Image 66: {\displaystyle \rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f7d439671d1289b6a816e6af7a304be40608d64), which is the density of the detonation products. The parameters ![Image 67: {\displaystyle A}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7daff47fa58cdfd29dc333def748ff5fa4c923e3), ![Image 68: {\displaystyle B}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/47136aad860d145f75f3eed3022df827cee94d7a), ![Image 69: {\displaystyle R_{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c1d63c96f59d98589d923c4f0b04222feaa7283e), ![Image 70: {\displaystyle R_{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/35f571121c264178676d1df8ab899f238a39bc2c) and ![Image 71: {\displaystyle \omega }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/48eff443f9de7a985bb94ca3bde20813ea737be8) are given by several references.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#cite_note-Dobratz-40) In addition, the initial density (solid part) ![Image 72: {\displaystyle \rho _{0}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d9c04a9d26b86af8c6205ba2a6287fd655b6b714), speed of detonation ![Image 73: {\displaystyle V_{D}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/499c0305c10b57061914df97a42583a302f79994), Chapman–Jouguet pressure ![Image 74: {\displaystyle P_{CJ}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/903cd2641d6ce7c6b3f2f2415e23a12fd18f80ec) and the chemical energy per unit volume of the explosive ![Image 75: {\displaystyle e_{0}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/51703931b2ce836f3a377076756262596e4348e3) are given in such references. These parameters are obtained by fitting the JWL-EOS to experimental results. Typical parameters for some explosives are listed in the table below.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas:
Title: Real gas

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas

Published Time: 2004-12-12T08:43:37Z

Markdown Content:
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

**Real gases** are non-ideal gases whose molecules occupy space and have interactions; consequently, they do not adhere to the [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law"). To understand the behaviour of real gases, the following must be taken into account:

*   [compressibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility "Compressibility") effects;
*   variable [specific heat capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specific_heat_capacity "Specific heat capacity");
*   [van der Waals forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_force "Van der Waals force");
*   non-equilibrium thermodynamic effects;
*   issues with molecular dissociation and elementary reactions with variable composition

For most applications, such a detailed analysis is unnecessary, and the [ideal gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas "Ideal gas") approximation can be used with reasonable accuracy. On the other hand, real-gas models have to be used near the [condensation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condensation "Condensation") point of gases, near [critical points](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics) "Critical point (thermodynamics)"), at very high pressures, to explain the [Joule–Thomson effect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joule%E2%80%93Thomson_effect "Joule–Thomson effect"), and in other less usual cases. The deviation from ideality can be described by the [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor") Z.

[![Image 1](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Real_Gas_Isotherms.svg/330px-Real_Gas_Isotherms.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Real_Gas_Isotherms.svg)

[Isotherms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isothermal_process "Isothermal process") of real gas
Dark blue curves – isotherms below the critical temperature. Green sections – [metastable states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metastability "Metastability").

The section to the left of point F – normal liquid.

 Point F – [boiling point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boiling_point "Boiling point").

 Line FG – [equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium") of liquid and gaseous phases.

 Section FA – [superheated liquid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superheating "Superheating").

 Section F′A – [stretched liquid](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stretched_liquid&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stretched liquid (page does not exist)") (p<0).

 Section AC – [analytic continuation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_continuation "Analytic continuation") of isotherm, physically impossible.

 Section CG – [supercooled vapor](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Supercooled_vapor&action=edit&redlink=1 "Supercooled vapor (page does not exist)").

 Point G – [dew point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dew_point "Dew point").

 The plot to the right of point G – normal gas.

 Areas FAB and GCB are equal.

Red curve – Critical isotherm.

 Point K – [critical point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics) "Critical point (thermodynamics)").

Light blue curves – supercritical isotherms

### Van der Waals model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Van der Waals model")]

Real gases are often modeled by taking into account their molar weight and molar volume ![Image 2: {\displaystyle RT=\left(p+{\frac {a}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/613d3684c4cc8808dedc71f0b51692f0acde76c8)

or alternatively: ![Image 3: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a}{V_{m}^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ffe4bea71e6ff3b217214da0a5e17d044613bfe1)

Where _p_ is the pressure, _T_ is the temperature, _R_ the ideal gas constant, and _V_ m the [molar volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molar_volume "Molar volume"). _a_ and _b_ are parameters that are determined empirically for each gas, but are sometimes estimated from their [critical temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_temperature "Critical temperature") (_T_ c) and [critical pressure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_pressure "Critical pressure") (_p_ c) using these relations: ![Image 4: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {27R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{64p_{\text{c}}}},&b&={\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{8p_{\text{c}}}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e10cc0f7dc5595da36b81d4b9dc17157e24f125c)

The constants at critical point can be expressed as functions of the parameters a, b: ![Image 5: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}p_{c}&={\frac {a}{27b^{2}}},&V_{m,c}&=3b,\\[2pt]T_{c}&={\frac {8a}{27bR}},&Z_{c}&={\frac {3}{8}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/452744ebd479362fd083d21e706fccc095309e62)

With the [reduced properties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduced_properties "Reduced properties")![Image 6: {\displaystyle p_{r}=p/p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3d0f60f2b101fd90cf9e95bc128343f7aaa6605e), ![Image 7: {\displaystyle V_{r}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{m,c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0028ee5fb82d7974988c13be1d9904273120db0d), ![Image 8: {\displaystyle T_{r}=T/T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9b197f0ff2f8025409c52052f07f668f0a52c033) the equation can be [written in the _reduced form_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_of_corresponding_states "Theorem of corresponding states"): ![Image 9: {\displaystyle p_{r}={\frac {8}{3}}{\frac {T_{r}}{V_{r}-{\frac {1}{3}}}}-{\frac {3}{V_{r}^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ce2999e719c46e18c73547eab4667d3166919747)

### Redlich–Kwong model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Redlich–Kwong model")]

[![Image 10](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Critical_isotherm_Redlich-Kwong_model.png/330px-Critical_isotherm_Redlich-Kwong_model.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Critical_isotherm_Redlich-Kwong_model.png)

Critical isotherm for Redlich-Kwong model in comparison to van-der-Waals model and ideal gas (with V 0=RT c/p c)

The [Redlich–Kwong equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state "Redlich–Kwong equation of state") is another two-parameter equation that is used to model real gases. It is almost always more accurate than the [van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation"), and often more accurate than some equations with more than two parameters. The equation is ![Image 11: {\displaystyle RT=\left(p+{\frac {a}{{\sqrt {T}}V_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5586ff699d882487b859a85c337c439bcd6ac993)

or alternatively: ![Image 12: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{{\sqrt {T}}V_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1223f4d1c39ba535fc7a14d9dc917968ac464e69)

where _a_ and _b_ are two empirical parameters that are **not** the same parameters as in the van der Waals equation. These parameters can be determined: ![Image 13: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&=0.42748\,{\frac {R^{2}{T_{\text{c}}}^{\frac {5}{2}}}{p_{\text{c}}}},\\[2pt]b&=0.08664\,{\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{p_{\text{c}}}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9e2fbac2964b81310524782791854a1e0e1833d6)

The constants at critical point can be expressed as functions of the parameters _a_, _b_: ![Image 14: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}p_{c}&={\left[{\frac {({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)^{7}}{3}}\,R\,{\frac {a^{2}}{b^{5}}}\right]}^{1/3},&V_{m,c}&={\frac {b}{{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}},\\[4pt]T_{c}&={\left[3{\left({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1\right)}^{2}{\frac {a}{bR}}\right]}^{2/3},&Z_{c}&={\frac {1}{3}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0d3bba92f778db56afed69f87d00a9e9ca1e0904)

Using ![Image 15: {\displaystyle p_{r}=p/p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3d0f60f2b101fd90cf9e95bc128343f7aaa6605e), ![Image 16: {\displaystyle V_{r}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{m,c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0028ee5fb82d7974988c13be1d9904273120db0d), ![Image 17: {\displaystyle T_{r}=T/T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9b197f0ff2f8025409c52052f07f668f0a52c033) the equation of state can be written in the _reduced form_: ![Image 18: {\displaystyle p_{r}={\frac {3T_{r}}{V_{r}-b'}}-{\frac {1}{b'{\sqrt {T_{r}}}V_{r}\left(V_{r}+b'\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a1841e8f1aabb4123b9bbcbff5ead8b6f95f2856) with ![Image 19: {\displaystyle b'={\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1\approx 0.26}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/578b7130159a520fdd079b4a4857ef08fc6e898f)

### Berthelot and modified Berthelot model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Berthelot and modified Berthelot model")]

The Berthelot equation (named after D. Berthelot)[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-1) is very rarely used, ![Image 20: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{TV_{\text{m}}^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7a9df16a18c22e4e68555bf53f6eac7564c36435)

but the modified version is somewhat more accurate ![Image 21: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}}}\left[1+{\frac {9}{128}}\cdot {\frac {p}{p_{c}}}\cdot {\frac {T_{c}}{T}}\left(1-6{\frac {T_{\text{c}}^{2}}{T^{2}}}\right)\right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b3519e2ba24083ffe59e3afdc6488152dad36192)

This model (named after C. Dieterici[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-2)) fell out of usage in recent years ![Image 22: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}\exp \left(-{\frac {a}{V_{\text{m}}RT}}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78b6f57938ceba245a72be7bab56609ead63c246)

with parameters a, b. These can be normalized by dividing with the critical point state[[note 1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-3):![Image 23: {\displaystyle {\tilde {p}}=p{\frac {(2be)^{2}}{a}};\quad {\tilde {T}}=T{\frac {4bR}{a}};\quad {\tilde {V}}_{m}=V_{m}{\frac {1}{2b}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1abfea9bd65db3373b933b1bb9f12bf2c1d14c95)which casts the equation into the [reduced form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_of_corresponding_states "Theorem of corresponding states"):[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-4)![Image 24: {\displaystyle {\tilde {p}}\left(2{\tilde {V}}_{m}-1\right)={\tilde {T}}\exp \left(2-{\frac {2}{{\tilde {T}}{\tilde {V}}_{m}}}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5ca2265442dbc0544289309a3a7e3b5a24c1e365)

The Clausius equation (named after [Rudolf Clausius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Clausius "Rudolf Clausius")) is a very simple three-parameter equation used to model gases. ![Image 25: {\displaystyle RT=\left(p+{\frac {a}{T{\left(V_{\text{m}}+c\right)}^{2}}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6e52f9809b27cf00594232d54318bc0af9327c51)

or alternatively: ![Image 26: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{T\left(V_{\text{m}}+c\right)^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81dfc8507daa71fc22aeab3f757bbb9cb7d64580)

where ![Image 27: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {27R^{2}T_{\text{c}}^{3}}{64p_{\text{c}}}},\\[4pt]b&=V_{\text{c}}-{\frac {RT_{\text{c}}}{4p_{\text{c}}}},\\[4pt]c&={\frac {3RT_{\text{c}}}{8p_{\text{c}}}}-V_{\text{c}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4d89d1316a2120bcd4601ddb0800fad5f643d0b2)

where _V_ c is critical volume.

The [Virial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_coefficient "Virial coefficient") equation derives from a [perturbative treatment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory "Perturbation theory") of statistical mechanics. ![Image 28: {\displaystyle pV_{\text{m}}=RT\left[1+{\frac {B(T)}{V_{\text{m}}}}+{\frac {C(T)}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}+{\frac {D(T)}{V_{\text{m}}^{3}}}+\cdots \right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c9eebec775b547603397c735dda026641ec5e853)

or alternatively ![Image 29: {\displaystyle pV_{\text{m}}=RT\left[1+B'(T)p+C'(T)p^{2}+D'(T)p^{3}+\cdots \right]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6a36ae0565ecdfd65defd0d41902045ee3d7b6dd)

where _A_, _B_, _C_, _A_′, _B_′, and _C_′ are temperature dependent constants.

### Peng–Robinson model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Peng–Robinson model")]

[Peng–Robinson equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peng%E2%80%93Robinson_equation_of_state "Peng–Robinson equation of state") (named after [D.-Y. Peng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D.-Y._Peng "D.-Y. Peng") and D. B. Robinson[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-5)) has the interesting property being useful in modeling some liquids as well as real gases. ![Image 30: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a(T)}{V_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}+b\right)+b\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/686240e75e093f07cc40ad0a2c64570fe957d8e5)

[![Image 31](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Isotherm_wohl_model.png/330px-Isotherm_wohl_model.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Isotherm_wohl_model.png)

Isotherm (V/V 0->p_r) at critical temperature for Wohl model, van der Waals model and ideal gas model (with V 0=RT c/p c)

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/ZPhCh87p9f.png/250px-ZPhCh87p9f.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ZPhCh87p9f.png)

Untersuchungen über die Zustandsgleichung, pp.9,10, _Zeitschr. f. Physikal. Chemie 87_

The Wohl equation (named after A. Wohl[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-6)) is formulated in terms of critical values, making it useful when real gas constants are not available, but it cannot be used for high densities, as for example the critical isotherm shows a drastic _decrease_ of pressure when the volume is contracted beyond the critical volume. ![Image 33: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}-b}}-{\frac {a}{TV_{\text{m}}\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}}+{\frac {c}{T^{2}V_{\text{m}}^{3}}}\quad }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2282359d7942317550e9302a267af59fc5eba7c6)

or: ![Image 34: {\displaystyle \left(p-{\frac {c}{T^{2}V_{\text{m}}^{3}}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)=RT-{\frac {a}{TV_{\text{m}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b5980e71f29c0142afa71d86ddbfff78f0f8b2cd)

or, alternatively: ![Image 35: {\displaystyle RT=\left(p+{\frac {a}{TV_{\text{m}}(V_{\text{m}}-b)}}-{\frac {c}{T^{2}V_{\text{m}}^{3}}}\right)\left(V_{\text{m}}-b\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0cea2ebbd3453a84c3c6f1cc95aa184bbfed33f0)

where ![Image 36: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&=6p_{\text{c}}T_{\text{c}}V_{\text{m,c}}^{2},&b&={\frac {V_{\text{m,c}}}{4}},\\[2pt]c&=4p_{\text{c}}T_{\text{c}}^{2}V_{\text{m,c}}^{3}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b07e2253de765b9d529d43df6a4036c8bc2a1b17) where ![Image 37: {\displaystyle V_{\text{m,c}}={\frac {4}{15}}{\frac {RT_{c}}{p_{c}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/21221ddfb590e2ffc55a7ad52b14b5a745d80170), ![Image 38: {\displaystyle p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f22f743ffb43cb8d64ef095c95ab2f86d9a631fe), ![Image 39: {\displaystyle T_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/66261e3cbed8035b2bf7a9ccb878c786cf7556c6) are (respectively) the molar volume, the pressure and the temperature at the [critical point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics) "Critical point (thermodynamics)").

And with the [reduced properties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduced_properties "Reduced properties")![Image 40: {\displaystyle p_{r}=p/p_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3d0f60f2b101fd90cf9e95bc128343f7aaa6605e), ![Image 41: {\displaystyle V_{r}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{m,c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0028ee5fb82d7974988c13be1d9904273120db0d), ![Image 42: {\displaystyle T_{r}=T/T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9b197f0ff2f8025409c52052f07f668f0a52c033) one can write the first equation in the _reduced form_: ![Image 43: {\displaystyle p_{r}={\frac {15}{4}}{\frac {T_{r}}{V_{r}-{\frac {1}{4}}}}-{\frac {6}{T_{r}V_{r}\left(V_{r}-{\frac {1}{4}}\right)}}+{\frac {4}{T_{r}^{2}V_{r}^{3}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a8e3f96644d399f5ac8ea7907634c135b6ef970c)

### Beattie–Bridgeman model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Beattie–Bridgeman model")]

[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-7) This equation is based on five experimentally determined constants. It is expressed as ![Image 44: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}\left(1-{\frac {c}{V_{\text{m}}T^{3}}}\right)(V_{\text{m}}+B)-{\frac {A}{V_{\text{m}}^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/93386c47a8afb4a5b068b774a636653d1d58f018)

where ![Image 45: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}A&=A_{0}\left(1-{\frac {a}{V_{\text{m}}}}\right),&B&=B_{0}\left(1-{\frac {b}{V_{\text{m}}}}\right)\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3b06a498bfa83134eebf1c3e363131f1b283a6ca)

This equation is known to be reasonably accurate for densities up to about 0.8 _ρ_ cr, where _ρ_ cr is the density of the substance at its critical point. The constants appearing in the above equation are available in the following table when _p_ is in kPa, _V_ m is in ![Image 46: {\displaystyle {\frac {{\text{m}}^{3}}{{\text{k}}\,{\text{mol}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/04a55a5232ab63537d1e8839b212c8f480b87421), _T_ is in K and ![Image 47: {\displaystyle R=8.314\mathrm {\frac {kPa\cdot m^{3}}{kmol\cdot K}} }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/918a047a090dcad456c43131fcfbb0c0de42b8e1)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#cite_note-8)

| Gas | _A_ 0 | _a_ | _B_ 0 | _b_ | _c_ |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Air | 131.8441 | 0.01931 | 0.04611 | −0.001101 | 4.34×10 4 |
| Argon, Ar | 130.7802 | 0.02328 | 0.03931 | 0.0 | 5.99×10 4 |
| Carbon dioxide, CO 2 | 507.2836 | 0.07132 | 0.10476 | 0.07235 | 6.60×10 5 |
| Ethane, C 2 H 6 | 595.791 | 0.05861 | 0.09400 | 0.01915 | 90.00×10 4 |
| Helium, He | 2.1886 | 0.05984 | 0.01400 | 0.0 | 40 |
| Hydrogen, H 2 | 20.0117 | −0.00506 | 0.02096 | −0.04359 | 504 |
| Methane, CH 4 | 230.7069 | 0.01855 | 0.05587 | -0.01587 | 12.83×10 4 |
| Nitrogen, N 2 | 136.2315 | 0.02617 | 0.05046 | −0.00691 | 4.20×10 4 |
| Oxygen, O 2 | 151.0857 | 0.02562 | 0.04624 | 0.004208 | 4.80×10 4 |

### Benedict–Webb–Rubin model

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Benedict–Webb–Rubin model")]

The BWR equation, ![Image 48: {\displaystyle p=RTd+d^{2}\left(RT(B+bd)-\left(A+ad-a\alpha d^{4}\right)-{\frac {1}{T^{2}}}\left[C-cd\left(1+\gamma d^{2}\right)\exp \left(-\gamma d^{2}\right)\right]\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/08d43caaf20d4f8946f7449bba37b3849305619e)

where _d_ is the molar density and where _a_, _b_, _c_, _A_, _B_, _C_, _α_, and _γ_ are empirical constants. Note that the _γ_ constant is a derivative of constant _α_ and therefore almost identical to 1.

Thermodynamic expansion work
----------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Real_gas&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Thermodynamic expansion work")]

The expansion work of the real gas is different than that of the ideal gas by the quantity ![Image 49: {\displaystyle \int _{V_{i}}^{V_{f}}\left({\frac {RT}{V_{m}}}-P_{\text{real}}\right)dV}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7f023f95c8f478c7433e2d24fccd56bd7087c6aa).

*   [Compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor")
*   [Equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state "Equation of state")
*   [Ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law"): [Boyle's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boyle%27s_law "Boyle's law") and [Gay-Lussac's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gay-Lussac%27s_law "Gay-Lussac's law")
