Title: Redlich–Kwong equation of state

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state

Published Time: 2008-10-19T23:17:47Z

Markdown Content:
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

In [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics") and [thermodynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamics "Thermodynamics"), the **Redlich–Kwong [equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state "Equation of state")** is an empirical, algebraic equation that relates temperature, pressure, and volume of gases. It is generally more accurate than the [van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation") and the [ideal gas equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law") at temperatures above the [critical temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_temperature "Critical temperature"). It was formulated by [Otto Redlich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Redlich "Otto Redlich") and [Joseph Neng Shun Kwong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Neng_Shun_Kwong "Joseph Neng Shun Kwong") in 1949.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Murdock2-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Kwong2-2) It showed that a two-parameter, cubic equation of state could well reflect reality in many situations, standing alongside the much more complicated [Beattie–Bridgeman model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#Beattie.E2.80.93Bridgeman_model "Real gas") and [Benedict–Webb–Rubin equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedict%E2%80%93Webb%E2%80%93Rubin_equation "Benedict–Webb–Rubin equation") that were used at the time. Although it was initially developed for gases, the Redlich–Kwong equation has been considered the most modified equation of state since those modifications have been aimed to generalize the predictive results obtained from it.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:02-3) Although this equation is not currently employed in practical applications,[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-4) modifications derived from this mathematical model like the Soave Redlich-Kwong (SRK), and [Peng Robinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peng-Robinson_equation "Peng-Robinson equation") have been improved and currently used in simulation and research of [vapor–liquid equilibria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:02-3)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-5)

The Redlich–Kwong equation is formulated as:[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Murdock-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-McQuarrie-7)![Image 1: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a}{{\sqrt {T}}\;V_{m}\,(V_{m}+b)}},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5c31c229dbe0f09f36bb0bbe29e807e8531834dd)

where:

*   _p_ is the gas [pressure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure "Pressure")
*   _R_ is the [gas constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_constant "Gas constant"),
*   _T_ is [temperature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature "Temperature"),
*   _V_ m is the [molar volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molar_volume "Molar volume") (_V_/_n_),
*   _a_ is a constant that corrects for attractive potential of molecules, and
*   _b_ is a constant that corrects for volume.

The constants are different depending on which gas is being analyzed. The constants can be calculated from the critical point data of the gas:[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Murdock-6)

![Image 2: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {1}{9({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)}}\,{\frac {R^{2}\,{T_{c}}^{2.5}}{P_{c}}}=0.42748\,{\frac {R^{2}\,{T_{c}}^{2.5}}{P_{c}}},\\[1ex]b&={\frac {{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}{3}}\,{\frac {R\,T_{c}}{P_{c}}}=0.08664\,{\frac {R\,T_{c}}{P_{c}}},\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6b1691aa4bb0bf59e91c58d60aec1f073e6a2d23)

where:

*   _T c_ is the temperature at the [critical point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics) "Critical point (thermodynamics)"), and
*   _P c_ is the pressure at the critical point.

The Redlich–Kwong equation can also be represented as an equation for the [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor") of gas, as a function of temperature and pressure:[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Kwong-8)

![Image 3: {\displaystyle Z={\frac {p\,V_{m}}{R\,T}}={\frac {1}{1-h}}\ -{\frac {A^{2}}{B}}{\frac {h}{1+h}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2a5efac7631f17bec501f941e041fb0775230888)

where:

*   ![Image 4: {\displaystyle A^{2}={\frac {a}{R^{2}\,T^{5/2}}}={\frac {0.42748\,{T_{c}}^{5/2}}{P_{c}\,T^{5/2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a2e2cb7faaddef70e66a2d780c6f6804b64d987a)
*   ![Image 5: {\displaystyle B={\frac {b}{R\,T}}={\frac {0.08664\,T_{c}}{P_{c}\,T}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fd15e43cce4900ba595ed9367be2beb34c26574a)
*   ![Image 6: {\displaystyle h={\frac {B\,p}{Z}}={\frac {b}{V_{m}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2c8020f3defc3f79db0a49b0c048d0787dcfec2e)

Or more simply: ![Image 7: {\displaystyle Z={\frac {pV_{m}}{RT}}={\frac {V_{m}}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a}{RT^{3/2}\left(V_{m}+b\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d4f8bf4919c5cb7f966bdc626e4fd42bf3d3fcd3)

This equation only implicitly gives Z as a function of pressure and temperature, but is easily solved numerically, originally by graphical interpolation, and now more easily by computer. Moreover, analytic solutions to [cubic functions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_function "Cubic function") have been known for centuries and are even faster for computers. The Redlich-Kwong equation of state may also be expressed as a cubic function of the molar volume.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-McQuarrie-7)

For all Redlich–Kwong gases:

![Image 8: {\displaystyle Z_{c}={\frac {1}{3}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fe496c95aa227543dee51f007cf377719e31c2d9)

where:

*   _Z c_ is the compressibility factor at the critical point

[![Image 9](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/RK_graph.png/250px-RK_graph.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:RK_graph.png)

Redlich-Kwong graph of Pr(Vr) and Z(Pr) at constant Tr.

Using ![Image 10: {\displaystyle p_{r}=p/P_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6442a3fe04641e8b94bdfffd8a714e484d3e7670), ![Image 11: {\displaystyle V_{r}=V_{\text{m}}/V_{\text{m,c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0028ee5fb82d7974988c13be1d9904273120db0d), ![Image 12: {\displaystyle T_{r}=T/T_{\text{c}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9b197f0ff2f8025409c52052f07f668f0a52c033) the equation of state can be written in the _reduced form_:

![Image 13: {\displaystyle p_{r}={\frac {Z_{c}^{-1}T_{r}}{V_{r}-0.08664Z_{c}^{-1}}}-{\frac {0.42748Z_{c}^{-2}}{{\sqrt {T_{r}}}V_{r}\left(V_{r}+{0.08664}Z_{c}^{-1}\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dd3b1dace7fcb26f9233ca13c55706422ab7bfeb)

And since ![Image 14: {\displaystyle Z_{c}^{-1}=3}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f590f8a94dc72c3d16895fba79c665531acf36f2) it follows: ![Image 15: {\displaystyle p_{r}={\frac {3T_{r}}{V_{r}-b'}}-{\frac {1}{b'{\sqrt {T_{r}}}V_{r}\left(V_{r}+b'\right)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a1841e8f1aabb4123b9bbcbff5ead8b6f95f2856) with ![Image 16: {\displaystyle b'={\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1\approx 0.26}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/578b7130159a520fdd079b4a4857ef08fc6e898f)

From the Redlich–Kwong equation, the [fugacity coefficient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fugacity_coefficient "Fugacity coefficient") of a gas can be estimated:[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Kwong-8)

![Image 17: {\displaystyle \ln \phi =\int _{0}^{P}{{\frac {Z-1}{p}}dP}=Z-1-\ln \left(Z-B\,P\right)-{\frac {A^{2}}{B}}\,\ln \left(1+{\frac {B\,P}{Z}}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9d9da8bf7b25d42dc5136238d32731cdb5bed0c3)

It is possible to express the critical constants _T c_ and _P c_ as functions of _a_ and _b_ by reversing the following system of 2 equations _a_(_T_ c, _P_ c) and _b_(_T_ c, _P_ c) with 2 variables _T_ c, _P_ c:

![Image 18: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {1}{9({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)}}\,{\frac {R^{2}\,{T_{c}}^{5/2}}{P_{c}}}={\frac {1}{9({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)}}\,{\frac {R^{2}\,{T_{c}}^{5/2}}{{\frac {{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}{3}}\,{\frac {R\,T_{c}}{b}}}}\\[1ex]\implies a&={\frac {bR\,{T_{c}}^{3/2}}{3{\left({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1\right)}^{2}}}\\[1ex]\implies T_{c}&=3^{2/3}{\left({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1\right)}^{4/3}{\left({\frac {a}{bR}}\right)}^{2/3}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e4b1b311b1f0668e67b6bea108f85556e3edb062)![Image 19: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}b&={\frac {{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}{3}}\,{\frac {R\,T_{c}}{P_{c}}}\\[1ex]\implies P_{c}&={\frac {{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}{3}}\,{\frac {R\,T_{c}}{b}}\\[1ex]\implies P_{c}&={\frac {({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)^{7/3}}{3^{1/3}}}R^{1/3}{\frac {a^{2/3}}{b^{5/3}}}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/926e38e95dd16ad6c6010291326f948e3be7754e)

Because of the definition of [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor") at critical condition, it is possible to reverse it to find the critical molar volume _V m,c_, by knowing previous found _P c_, _T c_ and _Z c_=1/3.

![Image 20: {\displaystyle Z={\frac {PV_{m}}{RT}}\implies Z_{c}={\frac {P_{c}V_{m,c}}{RT_{c}}}\implies V_{m,c}=Z_{c}{\frac {RT_{c}}{P_{c}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/460d8055675daadfd7e3eed495fa43381c2d8395)

![Image 21: {\displaystyle V_{m,c}={\frac {R}{3}}{\frac {3^{2/3}({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)^{4/3}({\frac {a}{bR}})^{2/3}}{{\frac {({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)^{7/3}}{3^{1/3}}}R^{1/3}{\frac {a^{2/3}}{b^{5/3}}}}}={\frac {R}{3}}{\frac {3b}{R({\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1)}}={\frac {b}{{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5053621f5f313d0cbc3257b1accf8c27a6de55d1)

### Multiple components

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Multiple components")]

The Redlich–Kwong equation was developed with an intent to also be applicable to mixtures of gases. In a mixture, the _b_ term, representing the volume of the molecules, is an average of the b values of the components, weighted by the mole fractions:

![Image 22: {\displaystyle b=\sum _{i}\sum _{j}x_{i}\,x_{j}b_{ij},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5d36f5b6648c90c1451d6ef9e77abbcf97bb0728) or ![Image 23: {\displaystyle B=\sum _{i}x_{i}\,B_{i}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d028403d9ecb030fe9a3ded7f8145a5b1aadc0b3)

where:

*   _x_ _i_ is the [mole fraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mole_fraction "Mole fraction") of the _i_ th component of the mixture,
*   _b_ _ij_ is the covolume parameter of the _i-j_ pair in the mixture, and
*   _B_ _i_ is the _B_ value of the _i_ th component of the mixture

The cross-terms of _b_ _ij_ (i.e. terms for which ![Image 24: {\displaystyle i\neq j}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d95aeb406bb427ac96806bc00c30c91d31b858be)), are commonly computed as

![Image 25: {\displaystyle b_{ij}={\frac {b_{i}+b_{j}}{2}}(1-l_{ij}),}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9c2f322fb38d6b0318f04f5dd64643da2816b9af)

where ![Image 26: {\displaystyle l_{ij}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/45d431596818cc830a50eb78ee48d7013f87713a) is an often empirically fitted interaction parameter accounting for asymmetry in the cross interactions.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:0-9)

The constant representing the attractive forces, _a_, is not linear with respect to mole fraction, but rather depends on the square of the mole fractions. That is:

![Image 27: {\displaystyle a=\sum _{i}\sum _{j}x_{i}\,x_{j}\,a_{i\,j}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f537b85510701a9010b7b5af61a1752fa375dfc2)

where:

*   _a_ _i_ _j_ is the attractive term between a molecule of species _i_ and species _j_,
*   _x_ _i_ is the [mole fraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mole_fraction "Mole fraction") of the _i_ th component of the mixture, and
*   _x_ _j_ is the [mole fraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mole_fraction "Mole fraction") of the _j_ th component of the mixture.

It is generally assumed that the attractive cross terms represent the geometric average of the individual _a_ terms, adjusted using an interaction parameter ![Image 28: {\displaystyle k_{ij}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9db60ff245b7d793444196f9f8f1c3f990180c7b), that is:[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:0-9)

![Image 29: {\displaystyle a_{i\,j}=(a_{i}\,a_{j})^{1/2}(1-k_{ij}),}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78349264346b85fe794f4856140ac3d612e08c05)

Where the interaction parameter ![Image 30: {\displaystyle k_{ij}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9db60ff245b7d793444196f9f8f1c3f990180c7b) is an often empirically fitted parameter accounting for asymmetry in the molecular cross-interactions.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:0-9) In this case, the following equation for the attractive term is furnished:

![Image 31: {\displaystyle A=\sum _{i}x_{i}\,A_{i}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0e60ebd17d1558d76f51f9294598ce109d993615)

where _A_ _i_ is the _A_ term for the _i'_ th component of the mixture.

These manners of creating _a_ and _b_ parameters for a mixture from the parameters of the pure fluids are commonly known as the van der Waals one-fluid mixing and combining rules.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-:0-9)

The [Van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation"), formulated in 1873 by [Johannes Diderik van der Waals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Diderik_van_der_Waals "Johannes Diderik van der Waals"), is generally regarded as the first somewhat realistic equation of state (beyond the ideal gas law):

![Image 32: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{V_{\mathrm {m} }-b}}-{\frac {a}{V_{\mathrm {m} }^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ef0c685d379f400b95b1734eeac01a2bdaa15f85)

However, its modeling of real behavior is not sufficient for many applications, and by 1949, had fallen out of favor, with the [Beattie–Bridgeman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_gas#Beattie.E2.80.93Bridgeman_model "Real gas") and [Benedict–Webb–Rubin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedict%E2%80%93Webb%E2%80%93Rubin_equation "Benedict–Webb–Rubin equation") equations of state being used preferentially, both of which contain more parameters than the Van der Waals equation.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-modify-10) The Redlich–Kwong equation was developed by Redlich and Kwong while they were both working for the [Shell Development Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shell_Development_Emeryville "Shell Development Emeryville") at [Emeryville, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emeryville,_California "Emeryville, California"). Kwong had begun working at Shell in 1944, where he met Otto Redlich when he joined the group in 1945. The equation arose out of their work at Shell - they wanted an easy, algebraic way to relate the pressures, volumes, and temperatures of the gasses they were working with - mostly non-polar and slightly polar hydrocarbons (the Redlich–Kwong equation is less accurate for hydrogen-bonding gases). It was presented jointly in [Portland, Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon "Portland, Oregon") at the _Symposium on Thermodynamics and Molecular Structure of Solutions_ in 1948, as part of the 14th Meeting of the [American Chemical Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Chemical_Society "American Chemical Society").[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-one-11) The success of the Redlich–Kwong equation in modeling many real gases accurately demonstrate that a cubic, two-parameter equation of state can give adequate results, if it is properly constructed. After they demonstrated the viability of such equations, many others created equations of similar form to try to improve on the results of Redlich and Kwong.

The equation is essentially empirical – the derivation is neither direct nor rigorous. The Redlich–Kwong equation is very similar to the Van der Waals equation, with only a slight modification being made to the attractive term, giving that term a temperature dependence. At high pressures, the volume of all gases approaches some finite volume, largely independent of temperature, that is related to the size of the gas molecules. This volume is reflected in the _b_ in the equation. It is empirically true that this volume is about 0.26 _V_ c (where V c is the volume at the critical point). This approximation is quite good for many small, non-polar compounds – the value ranges between about 0.24 _V_ c and 0.28V c.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Redlich1975-12) In order for the equation to provide a good approximation of volume at high pressures, it had to be constructed such that

![Image 33: {\displaystyle b=0.26\ V_{c}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0f9044d2885b214e2bd7ff5b2ee11da62f7c3df5)

The first term in the equation represents this high-pressure behavior.

The second term corrects for the attractive force of the molecules to each other. The functional form of _a_ with respect to the critical temperature and pressure is empirically chosen to give the best fit at moderate pressures for most relatively non-polar gasses.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-one-11)

The values of _a_ and _b_ are completely determined by the equation's shape and cannot be empirically chosen. Requiring it to hold at its critical point ![Image 34: {\displaystyle P=P_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2e62c87d279cde07ee6817e25750198960c7d784), ![Image 35: {\displaystyle V=V_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/091c93528950f401ce91aea5468e5585a99e74e7),

![Image 36: {\displaystyle P_{c}={\frac {R\,T_{c}}{V_{c}-b}}-{\frac {a}{{\sqrt {T_{c}}}\;V_{c}\,(V_{c}+b)}},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/85f67fc6bd2055a2ea81ac6147c05edf03336038)

enforcing the thermodynamic criteria for a critical point,

![Image 37: {\displaystyle \left({\frac {\partial P}{\partial V}}\right)_{T}=0,\left({\frac {\partial ^{2}P}{\partial V^{2}}}\right)_{T}=0,}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/48cb21298e2da7246f622b40c73007d53f719dc8)

and without loss of generality defining ![Image 38: {\displaystyle b=b'V_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e4e167df5886b93e6128ffecc4d081e9acfcfebe) and ![Image 39: {\displaystyle V_{c}=Z_{c}RT_{c}/P_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a3e551d1d9215d7aaa2d38c91288bcd061511001) yields 3 constraints,

![Image 40: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {(1+b')^{2}}{(b'-1)^{2}(2+b')}}{\frac {R^{2}T_{c}^{5/2}Z_{c}}{P_{c}}}\\[2pt]a&={\frac {(1+b')^{3}}{(1-b')^{3}(3+3b'+b'^{2})}}{\frac {R^{2}T_{c}^{5/2}Z_{c}}{P_{c}}}\\[2pt]a&={\frac {(1+b')(1-Z_{c}+b'Z_{c})}{b'-1}}{\frac {R^{2}T_{c}^{5/2}Z_{c}}{P_{c}}}.\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/adefcbfe96db0748e3824623d47d89b2b689a2bd)

Simultaneously solving these while requiring _b'_ and _Z c_ to be positive yields only one solution:

![Image 41: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}Z_{c}&={\frac {1}{3}},\qquad \qquad b'={\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1,\\[1ex]a&={\frac {P_{c}V_{c}^{2}{\sqrt {T_{c}}}}{b'}}={\frac {1}{{\sqrt[{3}]{2}}-1}}\,{\frac {R^{2}\,{T_{c}}^{5/2}}{9P_{c}}}.\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6e626dcd774e4b0efc0257b95202ef726eacf01c)

The Redlich–Kwong equation was designed largely to predict the properties of small, non-polar molecules in the vapor phase, which it generally does well. However, it has been subject to various attempts to refine and improve it. In 1975, Redlich himself published an equation of state adding a third parameter, in order to better model the behavior of both long-chained molecules, as well as more polar molecules. His 1975 equation was not so much a modification to the original equation as a re-inventing of a new equation of state, and was also formulated so as to take advantage of computer calculation, which was not available at the time the original equation was published.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Redlich1975-12) Many others have offered competing equations of state, either modifications to the original equation, or equations quite different in form. It was recognized by the mid 1960s that to significantly improve the equation, the parameters, especially _a_, would need to become temperature dependent. As early as 1966, Barner noted that the Redlich–Kwong equation worked best for molecules with an [acentric factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acentric_factor "Acentric factor") (ω) close to zero. He therefore proposed a modification to the attractive term:

![Image 42: {\displaystyle a=\alpha +\gamma \,T^{-1.5}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/543fb5c6b7a51fe233d71bff3778e066cebe2867)

where

*   α is the attractive term in the original Redlich–Kwong equation
*   γ is a parameter related to ω, with _γ_ = 0 for _ω_ = 0[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Barner-13)

It soon became desirable to obtain an equation that would also model well the [Vapor–liquid equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor%E2%80%93liquid_equilibrium "Vapor–liquid equilibrium") (VLE) properties of fluids, in addition to the vapor-phase properties.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-modify-10) Perhaps the best known application of the Redlich–Kwong equation was in calculating gas [fugacities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fugacity "Fugacity") of hydrocarbon mixtures, which it does well, that was then used in the VLE model developed by Chao and Seader in 1961.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-modify-10)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-14) However, in order for the Redlich–Kwong equation to stand on its own in modeling vapor–liquid equilibria, more substantial modifications needed to be made. The most successful of these modifications is the [Soave modification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state#Soave_modification_of_Redlich-Kwong "Equation of state") to the equation, proposed in 1972.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Soave-15) Soave's modification involved replacing the T 1/2 power found in the denominator attractive term of the original equation with a more complicated temperature-dependent expression. He presented the equation as follows:

![Image 43: {\displaystyle P={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a\,\alpha }{V_{m}(V_{m}+b)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33a9b02199864de27b2babd4509a23ea90adedfb)

where

The [Peng–Robinson equation of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peng%E2%80%93Robinson_equation_of_state "Peng–Robinson equation of state") further modified the Redlich–Kwong equation by modifying the attractive term, giving

![Image 44: {\displaystyle p={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a\,\alpha }{V_{m}\,(V_{m}+b)+b\,(V_{m}-b)}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/57eaab547b2ac1255e055f24611f49d97f5c9e36)

the parameters _a_, _b_, and _α_ are slightly modified, with[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Peng-16)

![Image 45: {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&={\frac {0.457235\,R^{2}\,T_{c}^{2}}{p_{c}}}\\b&={\frac {0.077796\,R\,T_{c}}{p_{c}}}\\\alpha &=\left(1+(0.37464+1.54226\omega -0.26992\omega ^{2})(1-{\sqrt {T_{r}}})\right)^{2}\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0cd3f236365df195c71ef51fed29f316efea1087)

The Peng–Robinson equation typically gives similar VLE equilibria properties as the Soave modification, but often gives better estimations of the liquid phase [density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density "Density").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-modify-10)

Several modifications have been made that attempt to more accurately represent the first term, related to the molecular size. The first significant modification of the repulsive term beyond the [Van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation")'s

![Image 46: {\displaystyle P_{\text{hs}}={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}-b}}={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}}}\,{\frac {1}{1-{\frac {b}{V_{m}}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dd324914b258a9026fb4200f2f633d21227e6367)

(where _P_ hs represents a [hard spheres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_spheres "Hard spheres") equation of state term.) was developed in 1963 by Thiele:[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Thiele-17)

![Image 47: {\displaystyle P_{\text{hs}}={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}}}\,{\frac {1-\eta ^{3}}{(1-\eta )^{4}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/57d60dd33d169150c7eac49dd632b357eb9458e3)

where ![Image 48: {\displaystyle \eta ={\frac {b}{4\,V_{m}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/22d2e08f88b79f9469b3f6047226aed54b1ae18e)

This expression was improved by Carnahan and Starling to give [[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Carbaham-18)

![Image 49: {\displaystyle P_{\text{hs}}={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}}}\,{\frac {1+\eta +\eta ^{2}-\eta ^{3}}{{\left(1-\eta \right)}^{3}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/91f7b3cf22167fa5003fda52fa5b865c9b098984)

The Carnahan-Starling hard-sphere equation of state has term been used extensively in developing other equations of state,[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-modify-10) and tends to give very good approximations for the repulsive term.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-why-19)

Beyond improved two-parameter equations of state, a number of three parameter equations have been developed, often with the third parameter depending on either Z c, the compressibility factor at the critical point, or ω, the acentric factor. Schmidt and Wenzel proposed an equation of state with an attractive term that incorporates the acentric factor:[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlich%E2%80%93Kwong_equation_of_state#cite_note-Schmidt-20)

![Image 50: {\displaystyle P={\frac {R\,T}{V_{m}-b}}-{\frac {a}{V_{m}^{2}+(1+3\,\omega )bV_{m}-3\omega b^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d39d45453ec7af995eebf9c69be76bb5c050ea13)

This equation reduces to the original Redlich–Kwong equation in the case when _ω_ = 0, and to the Peng–Robinson equation when _ω_ = 1/3.

Title: Statistical associating fluid theory

URL Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory

Published Time: 2022-10-03T15:50:23Z

Markdown Content:
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

**Statistical associating fluid theory** (**SAFT**) [[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2) is a [chemical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry") theory, based on [perturbation theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory "Perturbation theory"), that uses [statistical thermodynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_thermodynamics "Statistical thermodynamics") to explain how complex [fluids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluids "Fluids") and fluid mixtures form associations through [hydrogen bonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_bonds "Hydrogen bonds").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-John_Wiley_&_Sons,_Ltd-3) Widely used in industry and academia, it has become a standard approach for describing complex mixtures.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-4)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Economou2001-5)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-HuangRadosz1990-6)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-7) Since it was first proposed in 1990, SAFT has been used in a large number of molecular-based equation of state[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-8)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-9) models for describing the Helmholtz energy contribution due to association.

SAFT is a [Helmholtz energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy "Helmholtz free energy") term that can be used in [equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_state "Equation of state") that describe the [thermodynamic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic "Thermodynamic") and [phase equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_equilibrium "Phase equilibrium") properties of pure fluids and fluid mixtures. SAFT was developed using [statistical mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics "Statistical mechanics"). SAFT models the [Helmholtz free energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy "Helmholtz free energy") contribution due to [association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissociation_(chemistry) "Dissociation (chemistry)"), i.e. hydrogen bonding.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-DufalLafitteHaslam2015-10) SAFT can be used in combination with other Helmholtz free energy terms. Other Helmholtz energy contributions consider for example [Lennard-Jones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lennard-Jones_potential "Lennard-Jones potential") interactions, [covalent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covalent "Covalent") chain-forming bonds, and association (interactions between segments caused by, for example, hydrogen bonding).[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2) SAFT has been applied to a wide range of fluids, including [supercritical fluids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercritical_fluids "Supercritical fluids"), [polymers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymers "Polymers"), [liquid crystals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_crystals "Liquid crystals"), [electrolytes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrolytes "Electrolytes"), [surfactant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surfactant "Surfactant") solutions, and [refrigerants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refrigerants "Refrigerants").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Economou2001-5)

SAFT evolved from thermodynamic theories, including perturbation theories developed in the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s by John Barker and Douglas Henderson, [Keith Gubbins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keith_Gubbins "Keith Gubbins") and Chris Gray, and, in particular, [Michael Wertheim](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Michael_Wertheim&action=edit&redlink=1 "Michael Wertheim (page does not exist)")'s first-order, thermodynamic perturbation theory (TPT1) outlined in a series of papers in the 1980s.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2)[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-JiangHall2017-11)

The SAFT equation of state was developed using [statistical mechanical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics "Statistical mechanics") methods (in particular the [perturbation theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory "Perturbation theory") of Wertheim[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-12)) to describe the interactions between molecules in a system.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-1)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Chapman1988-13)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-14) The idea of a SAFT equation of state was first proposed by [Walter G. Chapman](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Walter_G._Chapman&action=edit&redlink=1 "Walter G. Chapman (page does not exist)") and by Chapman et al. in 1988 and 1989.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-1)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Chapman1988-13)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-14) Many different versions of the SAFT models have been proposed, but all use the same chain and association terms derived by Chapman et al.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Chapman1988-13)[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-15) One of the first SAFT papers (1990) titled "New reference equation of state for associating liquids" by Walter G. Chapman, Keith Gubbins, [George Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Jackson_(chemist) "George Jackson (chemist)"), and Maciej Radosz,[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2) was recognized in 2007 by _[Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial\_and\_Engineering\_Chemistry\_Research "Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research")_ as one of the most highly cited papers of the previous three decades.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-16) SAFT is one of the first theories to accurately describe (in comparison with molecular simulation) the effects on fluid properties of molecular size and shape in addition to association between molecules.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1989-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbinsJackson1990-2)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-Chapman1988-13)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-ChapmanGubbins1988-14)

Many variations of SAFT have been developed since the 1990s, including HR-SAFT (Huang-Radosz SAFT),[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-HuangRadosz1990-6)[PC-SAFT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PC-SAFT "PC-SAFT") (perturbed chain SAFT),[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-GrossSadowski2004-17)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-18) Polar SAFT,[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-JogChapman2001-19) PCP-SAFT (PC-polar-SAFT),[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-20)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-22) soft-SAFT,[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-23) polar soft-SAFT,[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-AlkhatibPereiraTorne2020-24) SAFT-VR (variable range),[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-McCabeJackson1999-25) SAFT VR-Mie.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-26) Also, the SAFT term was used in combination with [cubic equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_equations_of_state "Cubic equations of state") for describing the dispersive-repulsive interactions, for example in the Cubic-Plus-Association (CPA) equation of state model[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-KontogeorgisMichelsenFolas2006-27) and the SAFT + cubic model [[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-28) and non-random-lattice (NLF) models based on [lattice field theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_field_theory "Lattice field theory").[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-John_Wiley_&_Sons,_Ltd-3)

Association schemes
-------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Statistical_associating_fluid_theory&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Association schemes")]

The association term in SAFT (i.e. hydrogen bonding) is handled by assigning to each molecule a set of "association sites" that are permitted to form bonds with association sites on other molecules.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-:0-29) The strength of a bond between two sites is characterized by a bonding energy. In order to characterise different kinds of molecules and functional groups, a molecule or group is assigned one of many "association schemes",[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-:0-29) which are summarised in the (non-exhaustive) table below. These schemes are used to differentiate between the number of association sites a molecule has, and which other sites each site is permitted to bond to. In this system, each association scheme consists of a number and a letter. The number indicates how many association sites the molecule (or group) has, while the letters are used to differentiate between different schemes based on the permitted bonds. In the "A" schemes, all association sites can form bonds with all other sites, while in the "B" and "C" schemes, only certain sites are permitted to bond to certain other sites.

While the appropriate association scheme for a given molecule or group can in principle be deduced from the electronic structure, it is common to treat the association scheme heuristically, and to determine the best scheme by fitting to experimental data.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-30)[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_associating_fluid_theory#cite_note-31)

| Scheme | No. of sites | Permitted bonds | Example |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1A | 1 | A-A | Acid, tertiary amine |
| 2A | 2 | A-A, A-B, B-B |  |
| 2B | 2 | A-B | Secondary amine |
| 2C | 2 | A-A, A-B |  |
| 3A | 3 | A-A, A-B, A-C, B-B, B-C, C-C |  |
| 3B | 3 | A-C, B-C | Primary amine |
| 4A | 4 | A-A, A-B, A-C, A-D, B-B, B-C, B-D, C-C, C-D, D-D |  |
| 4B | 4 | A-D, B-D, C-D | Ammonia |
| 4C | 4 | A-C, A-D, B-C, B-D | Water |

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
	
This article is written like a textbook. Please help rewrite it in a neutral, encyclopedic style. Relevant discussion may be found on the talk page. (May 2025) (Learn how and when to remove this message)

The van der Waals equation is a mathematical formula that describes the behavior of real gases. It is an equation of state that relates the pressure, volume, number of molecules, and temperature in a fluid. The equation modifies the ideal gas law in two ways: first, it considers particles to have a finite diameter (whereas an ideal gas consists of point particles); second, its particles interact with each other (unlike an ideal gas, whose particles move as though alone in the volume).

The equation is named after Dutch physicist Johannes Diderik van der Waals, who first derived it in 1873 as part of his doctoral thesis. Van der Waals based the equation on the idea that fluids are composed of discrete particles, which few scientists believed existed. However, the equation accurately predicted the behavior of a fluid around its critical point, which had been discovered a few years earlier. Its qualitative and quantitative agreement with experiments ultimately cemented its acceptance in the scientific community. These accomplishments won van der Waals the 1910 Nobel Prize in Physics.[1] Today the equation is recognized as an important model of phase change processes.[2]

What is truly remarkable is the extent to which van der Waals succeeded. Indeed, Epstein in his classic thermodynamics textbook began his discussion of the van der Waals equation by writing, "Despite its simplicity, it comprehends both the gaseous and the liquid state and brings out, in a most remarkable way, all the phenomena pertaining to the continuity of these two states".[17] Also, in Volume 5 of his Lectures on Theoretical Physics, Sommerfeld, in addition to noting that "Boltzmann[18] described van der Waals as the Newton of real gases",[6] also wrote "It is very remarkable that the theory due to van der Waals is in a position to predict, at least qualitatively, the unstable [referring to superheated liquid, and subcooled vapor, now called metastable] states" that are associated with the phase change process.[19]

History[edit]

The first to propose a volume correction to Boyle's law was Daniel Bernoulli in his microscopic theory in Hydrodynamica, however this model was mostly ignored in 1738.[20]

In 1857 Rudolf Clausius published The Nature of the Motion which We Call Heat. In it he derived the relation

Hence temperature was proportional to the average kinetic energy of the particles.[21] This article inspired further work based on the twin ideas that substances are composed of indivisible particles, and that heat is a consequence of the particle motion; movement that evolves according to Newton's laws. The work, known as the kinetic theory of gases, was done principally by Clausius, James Clerk Maxwell, and Ludwig Boltzmann. At about the same time, Josiah Willard Gibbs advanced the work by converting it into statistical mechanics.[22][23]

This environment influenced Johannes Diderik van der Waals. After initially pursuing a teaching credential, he was accepted for doctoral studies at the University of Leiden under Pieter Rijke.[24] This led, in 1873, to a dissertation that provided a simple, particle-based equation that described the gas-liquid change of state, the origin of a critical temperature, and the concept of corresponding states.[25][26] The equation is based on two premises: first, that fluids are composed of particles with non-zero volumes, and second, that at a large enough distance each particle exerts an attractive force on all other particles in its vicinity. Boltzmann called these forces van der Waals cohesive forces.[27]

In 1869 Irish professor of chemistry Thomas Andrews at Queen's University Belfast, in a paper entitled On the Continuity of the Gaseous and Liquid States of Matter,[28] displayed an experimentally obtained set of isotherms of carbonic acid, H2CO3, that showed at low temperatures a jump in density at a certain pressure, while at higher temperatures there was no abrupt change (the figure can be seen here). Andrews called the isotherm at which the jump disappears the critical point. Given the similarity of the titles of this paper and van der Waals' subsequent thesis, one might think that van der Waals set out to develop a theoretical explanation of Andrews' experiments; however, this is not what happened. Van der Waals began work by trying to determine a molecular attraction that appeared in Laplace's theory of capillarity, and only after establishing his equation he tested it using Andrews' results.[29][30]

By 1877 sprays of both liquid oxygen and liquid nitrogen had been produced, and a new field of research, low-temperature physics, had been opened. The van der Waals equation played a part in all this, especially for the liquefaction of hydrogen and helium which was finally achieved in 1908.[31] From measurements of

Thus from two such measurements of pressure and temperature, one could determine

All this labor required considerable faith in the belief that gas–liquid systems were all basically the same, even if no one had ever seen the liquid phase. This faith arose out of the repeated success of the van der Waals theory, which is essentially a universal equation of state, independent of the details of any particular substance once it has been properly scaled. [...] As a result, not only was it possible to believe that hydrogen could be liquefied, but it was even possible to predict the necessary temperature and pressure.

Van der Waals was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1910, in recognition of the contribution of his formulation of this "equation of state for gases and liquids".

Use[edit]

The van der Waals equation has been, and remains, useful because:[34]

Its coefficient of thermal expansion has a simple analytic expression
It explains the existence of the critical point, and establishes the theorem of corresponding states
Its internal energy and entropy have simple analytic expressions
Its specific heat at constant volume 
𝑐
𝑣
 is a function of 
𝑇
 only
Its specific heat at constant pressure, 
𝑐
𝑝
 has a simple relationship with 
𝑐
𝑣
Its Joule–Thomson coefficient and associated inversion curve, which are instrumental in the commercial liquefaction of gases, have simple analytic expressions
Together with the Maxwell construction it explains the existence of the liquid–vapor phase transition, including the observed metastable states

In addition[35]

Its enthalpy and free energies all have simple analytic expressions
Its isothermal compressibility has a simple analytic expression
Its saturation curve has a simple analytic parametric solution
It is an intermediate mathematical model that is useful as a pedagogical tool when teaching physics, chemistry, and engineering

and

It plays an important role in the modern theory of phase transitions[36]
It is the completely accurate equation of state for substances whose intermolecular potential matches the Sutherland potential[37]

All the constants characterizing the gas have dropped out of this equation. If one bases measurements on the van der Waals units [Boltzmann's name for the reduced quantities here], then he obtains the same equation of state for all gases. [...] Only the values of the critical volume, pressure, and temperature depend on the nature of the particular substance; the numbers that express the actual volume, pressure, and temperature as multiples of the critical values satisfy the same equation for all substances. In other words, the same equation relates the reduced volume, reduced pressure, and reduced temperature for all substances.

Obviously such a broad general relation is unlikely to be correct; nevertheless, the fact that one can obtain from it an essentially correct description of actual phenomena is very remarkable.

Referring back to Figure 1, the isotherms for

=

/

 (green) isotherm consists of two separate segments. The solid green lines are composed of stable states. They terminate at dots representing the saturated liquid and vapor states forming the phase change. The dashed green lines represent metastable states (superheated liquid and subcooled vapor). They are created in the phase transition, have a finite lifetime, and then devolve into their lower energy stable alternative.

At every point in the region between the two curves in Figure 2, there are two states: one stable and one metastable. The coexistence of these states can be seen in Figure 1—for discontinuous isotherms, there are values of 
𝑝
r
 which correspond to two points on the isotherm: one on a solid line (the stable state) and one on a dashed region (the metastable state).

In his treatise of 1898, in which he described the van der Waals equation in great detail, Boltzmann discussed these metastable states in a section titled "Undercooling, Delayed evaporation".[70] (Today, these states are now denoted "subcooled vapor" and "superheated liquid".) Moreover, it has now become clear that these metastable states occur regularly in the phase transition process. In particular, processes that involve very high heat fluxes create large numbers of these states, and transition to their stable alternative with a corresponding release of energy that can be dangerous. Consequently, there is a pressing need to study their thermal properties.[71]

In the same section, Boltzmann also addressed and explained the negative pressures which some liquid metastable states exhibit (for example, the blue isotherm 
𝑇
r
=
4
/
5
 in Fig. 1). He concluded that such liquid states of tensile stresses were real, as did Tien and Lienhard many years later who wrote "The van der Waals equation predicts that at low temperatures liquids sustain enormous tension [...] In recent years measurements have been made that reveal this to be entirely correct."[72]

Even though the phase change produces a mathematical discontinuity in the homogeneous fluid properties (for example 
𝑣
), there is no physical discontinuity.[73] As the liquid begins to vaporize, the fluid becomes a heterogeneous mixture of liquid and vapor whose molar volume varies continuously from 
𝑣

Although this case is similar to that of a single fluid, here the geometry can be much more complex. The surface can develop a wave (called a plait or fold) in the 
𝑥

𝑣

Therefore, there can be two liquid phases that can be either miscible, or wholly or partially immiscible, as well as a vapor phase.[100][101] Despite a great deal of both theoretical and experimental work on this problem by van der Waals and his successors—work which produced much useful knowledge about the various types of phase equilibria that are possible in fluid mixtures[102]—complete solutions to the problem were only obtained after 1967, when the availability of modern computers made calculations of mathematical problems of this complexity feasible for the first time.[103] The results obtained were, in Rowlinson's words,[104]

a spectacular vindication of the essential physical correctness of the ideas behind the van der Waals equation, for almost every kind of critical behavior found in practice can be reproduced by the calculations, and the range of parameters that correlate with the different kinds of behavior are intelligible in terms of the expected effects of size and energy.

Validity of the equation[edit]

Since van der Waals presented his thesis, "[m]any derivations, pseudo-derivations, and plausibility arguments have been given" for it.[114] However, no mathematically rigorous derivation of the equation over its entire range of molar volume that begins from a statistical mechanical principle exists. Indeed, such a proof is not possible, even for hard spheres.[115][116][117][118][119] Goodstein writes, "Obviously the value of the van der Waals equation rests principally on its empirical behavior rather than its theoretical foundation."[7]

Although the use of the vdW equation is not justified mathematically, it has empirical validity. Its various applications in this region that attest to this, both qualitative and quantitative, have been described previously in this article. This point was also made by Alder, et al. who, at a conference marking the 100th anniversary of van der Waals' thesis, noted that:[120]

It is doubtful whether we would celebrate the centennial of the Van der Waals equation if it were applicable only under circumstances where it has been proven to be rigorously valid. It is empirically well established that many systems whose molecules have attractive potentials that are neither long-range nor weak conform nearly quantitatively to the Van der Waals model. An example is the theoretically much studied system of Argon, where the attractive potential has only a range half as large as the repulsive core.

They continued by saying that this model has "validity down to temperatures below the critical temperature, where the attractive potential is not weak at all but, in fact, comparable to the thermal energy." They also described its application to mixtures "where the Van der Waals model has also been applied with great success. In fact, its success has been so great that not a single other model of the many proposed since, has equalled its quantitative predictions,[121] let alone its simplicity."[122]

Engineers have made extensive use of this empirical validity, modifying the equation in numerous ways (by one account there have been some 400 cubic equations of state produced)[123] to manage the liquids,[124] and gases of pure substances and mixtures,[125] that they encounter in practice.

This situation has been aptly described by Boltzmann:[126]

... van der Waals has given us such a valuable tool that it would cost us much trouble to obtain by the subtlest deliberations a formula that would really be more useful than the one that van der Waals found by inspiration, as it were.

Title: Virial expansion

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

The **virial expansion** is a model of thermodynamic [equations of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equations_of_state "Equations of state"). It expresses the [pressure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure "Pressure")P of a gas in local [equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_equilibrium "Thermodynamic equilibrium") as a [power series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_series "Power series") of the [density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density "Density"). This equation may be represented in terms of the [compressibility factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compressibility_factor "Compressibility factor"), Z, as ![Image 1: {\displaystyle Z\equiv {\frac {P}{RT\rho }}=A+B\rho +C\rho ^{2}+\cdots }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4454a59b02abaa51db0cd44bbbc6b4fe9fe48ae4) This equation was first proposed by [Kamerlingh Onnes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heike_Kamerlingh_Onnes "Heike Kamerlingh Onnes").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-onnes-1) The terms A, B, and C represent the [virial coefficients](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_coefficients "Virial coefficients"). The leading coefficient A is defined as the constant value of 1, which ensures that the equation reduces to the [ideal gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas "Ideal gas") expression as the gas density approaches zero.

Second and third virial coefficients
------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Virial_expansion&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Second and third virial coefficients")]

The second, B, and third, C, virial coefficients have been studied extensively and tabulated for many fluids for more than a century. Two of the most extensive compilations are in the books by Dymond[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-2)[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-3) and the [National Institute of Standards and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institute_of_Standards_and_Technology "National Institute of Standards and Technology")'s Thermo Data Engine Database[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-4) and its Web Thermo Tables.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-5) Tables of second and third virial coefficients of many fluids are included in these compilations.

[![Image 2](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Argon_b_c.jpg/250px-Argon_b_c.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Argon_b_c.jpg)

The 2nd and 3rd virial coefficients of argon

Casting equations of the state into virial form
-----------------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Virial_expansion&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Casting equations of the state into virial form")]

Most equations of state can be reformulated and cast in virial equations to evaluate and compare their implicit second and third virial coefficients. The seminal [van der Waals equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_der_Waals_equation "Van der Waals equation") of state[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-6) was proposed in 1873: ![Image 3: {\displaystyle P={\frac {RT}{\left(v-b\right)}}-{\frac {a}{v^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a7438110c7e5f77123e4bc8f7312a247531a1463) where _v_ = 1/_ρ_ is [molar volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molar_volume "Molar volume"). It can be rearranged by expanding 1/(_v_ − _b_) into a [Taylor series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_series "Taylor series"): ![Image 4: {\displaystyle Z=1+\left(b-{\frac {a}{RT}}\right)\rho +b^{2}\rho ^{2}+b^{3}\rho ^{3}+\cdots }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2b6d1a5fcbc326f5ab1396e3287db27a9d4e79ef)

In the van der Waals equation, the second virial coefficient has roughly the correct behavior, as it decreases monotonically when the temperature is lowered. The third and higher virial coefficients are independent of temperature, and are not correct, especially at low temperatures.

Almost all subsequent equations of state are derived from the van der Waals equation, like those from Dieterici,[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-7) Berthelot,[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-8) Redlich-Kwong,[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-9) and Peng-Robinson[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-10) suffer from the singularity introduced by 1/(v - b).

Other equations of state, started by Beattie and Bridgeman,[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-11) are more closely related to virial equations, and show to be more accurate in representing behavior of fluids in both gaseous and liquid phases.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The Beattie-Bridgeman equation of state, proposed in 1928, ![Image 5: {\displaystyle p={\frac {RT}{v^{2}}}\left(1-{\frac {c}{vT^{3}}}\right)(v+B)-{\frac {A}{v^{2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0e28edbe1f3584a19bdb37c0096b8dae0972730f) where

*   ![Image 6: {\displaystyle A=A_{0}\left(1-{\frac {a}{v}}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4884725c31e3b4fd461c753040dea05099c2585d)
*   ![Image 7: {\displaystyle B=B_{0}\left(1-{\frac {b}{v}}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/74d3e233107c8b114a1d1b5c56ba51da4ccb94bf)

can be rearranged as ![Image 8: {\displaystyle Z=1+\left(B_{0}-{\frac {A_{0}}{RT}}-{\frac {c}{T^{3}}}\right)\rho -\left(B_{0}b-{\frac {A_{0}a}{RT}}+{\frac {B_{0}c}{T^{3}}}\right)\rho ^{2}+\left({\frac {B_{0}bc}{T^{3}}}\right)\rho ^{3}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4e0c5c0f9ac1d2b96da49a1de96034d14d7acced)The Benedict-Webb-Rubin equation of state[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-12) of 1940 represents better isotherms below the critical temperature: ![Image 9: {\displaystyle Z=1+\left(B_{0}-{\frac {A_{0}}{RT}}-{\frac {C_{0}}{RT^{3}}}\right)\rho +\left(b-{\frac {a}{RT}}\right)\rho ^{2}+\left({\frac {\alpha a}{RT}}\right)\rho ^{5}+{\frac {c\rho ^{2}}{RT^{3}}}\left(1+\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)\exp \left(-\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/38e72ac9f6374346d494706a881b292702965332)

More improvements were achieved by Starling[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-starling-13) in 1972: ![Image 10: {\displaystyle Z=1+\left(B_{0}-{\frac {A_{0}}{RT}}-{\frac {C_{0}}{RT^{3}}}+{\frac {D_{0}}{RT^{4}}}-{\frac {E_{0}}{RT^{5}}}\right)\rho +\left(b-{\frac {a}{RT}}-{\frac {d}{RT^{2}}}\right)\rho ^{2}+\alpha \left({\frac {a}{RT}}+{\frac {d}{RT^{2}}}\right)\rho ^{5}+{\frac {c\rho ^{2}}{RT^{3}}}\left(1+\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)\exp \left(-\gamma \rho ^{2}\right)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1c13ce1e553c338a85e4188fc0b4ec35dff4d760)

Following are plots of reduced second and third virial coefficients against reduced temperature according to Starling:[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virial_expansion#cite_note-starling-13)

[![Image 11](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/BWRS-reduced_1.jpg/250px-BWRS-reduced_1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BWRS-reduced_1.jpg)

The 2nd and 3rd virial coefficients for 12 fluids

The exponential terms in the last two equations correct the third virial coefficient so that the isotherms in the liquid phase can be represented correctly. The exponential term converges rapidly as ρ increases, and if only the first two terms in its Taylor expansion series are taken, ![Image 12: {\displaystyle 1-\gamma \rho ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/602fc5f3b031266767398b8bff2cfd5680575e20), and multiplied with ![Image 13: {\displaystyle 1+\gamma \rho ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a49950b8fc3116029f169fb540868f257d682af5), the result is ![Image 14: {\displaystyle 1-\gamma ^{2}\rho ^{4}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/379add8f193e53e2703968d210c8167073d28f23), which contributes a ![Image 15: {\displaystyle c/RT^{3}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ad38916fc993cfd401fd7583482e5bb020c10d56) term to the third virial coefficient, and one term to the eighth virial coefficient, which can be ignored.[_[original research?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No\_original\_research "Wikipedia:No original research")_]

After the expansion of the exponential terms, the Benedict-Webb-Rubin and Starling equations of state have this form: ![Image 16: {\displaystyle Z=1+b\rho _{r}+c\rho _{r}^{2}+f\rho _{r}^{5}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e99c7164ab90eb2f9876d4be0824c0d701887c74)

Cubic virial equation of state
------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Virial_expansion&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Cubic virial equation of state")]

The three-term virial equation or a cubic virial equation of state ![Image 17: {\displaystyle Z=1+B\rho +C\rho ^{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0caf1b70809ff1279a04dd815b4310a9d7d908f7) has the simplicity of the Van der Waals equation of state without its singularity at _v_ = _b_. Theoretically, the second virial coefficient represents bimolecular attraction forces, and the third virial term represents the repulsive forces among three molecules in close contact.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

With this cubic virial equation, the coefficients B and C can be solved in closed form. Imposing the critical conditions: ![Image 18: {\displaystyle {\frac {\mathrm {d} P}{\mathrm {d} v}}=0\qquad {\text{and}}\qquad {\frac {\mathrm {d} ^{2}P}{\mathrm {d} v^{2}}}=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a2fac5fceec344ad69a0bda821d1bef9cd81f71a) the cubic virial equation can be solved to yield: ![Image 19: {\displaystyle B=-v_{c},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d843ea2e9f4c7ee4f102cc6a0db9efa716616843)![Image 20: {\displaystyle C={\frac {v_{c}^{2}}{3}},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/deaaf66f62483bd7ce744ecff904ef16b210f693) and ![Image 21: {\displaystyle Z_{c}={\frac {P_{c}v_{c}}{RT_{c}}}={\frac {1}{3}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/beeb5b4258c153e73789d1c9af5a69f215c1d184)![Image 22: {\displaystyle Z_{c}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/55a143e5e31a61379597eabe309fcadf8fe88d4c) is therefore 0.333, compared to 0.375 from the Van der Waals equation.

Between the critical point and the [triple point](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_point "Triple point") is the saturation region of fluids. In this region, the gaseous phase coexists with the liquid phase under saturation pressure ![Image 23: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de8673536be352a48affb41ad7602843987f7864), and the saturation temperature ![Image 24: {\displaystyle T_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b300de9211a1c565e9ecaf816af66e5f50de73). Under the saturation pressure, the liquid phase has a molar volume of ![Image 25: {\displaystyle v_{\text{l}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33eaf96c44e80386e3169a7f8d9bc9688dd2b26b), and the gaseous phase has a molar volume of ![Image 26: {\displaystyle v_{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bfb34e5f296946ac152255310520ad4015a5d0c3). The corresponding molar densities are ![Image 27: {\displaystyle \rho _{\text{l}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/52156b40b9af43a5625b8567349ce32480bda878) and ![Image 28: {\displaystyle \rho _{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/526a0391957f0313e2369b7144d1deb2149b5131). These are the saturation properties needed to compute second and third virial coefficients.

A valid equation of state must produce an isotherm which crosses the horizontal line of ![Image 29: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de8673536be352a48affb41ad7602843987f7864) at ![Image 30: {\displaystyle v_{\text{l}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33eaf96c44e80386e3169a7f8d9bc9688dd2b26b) and ![Image 31: {\displaystyle v_{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bfb34e5f296946ac152255310520ad4015a5d0c3), on ![Image 32: {\displaystyle T_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b300de9211a1c565e9ecaf816af66e5f50de73).[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Under ![Image 33: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de8673536be352a48affb41ad7602843987f7864) and ![Image 34: {\displaystyle T_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b300de9211a1c565e9ecaf816af66e5f50de73), gas is in equilibrium with liquid. This means that the PρT isotherm has three roots at ![Image 35: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de8673536be352a48affb41ad7602843987f7864). The cubic virial equation of state at ![Image 36: {\displaystyle T_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b300de9211a1c565e9ecaf816af66e5f50de73) is: ![Image 37: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}=RT_{\text{sat}}\left(1+B\rho +C\rho ^{2}\right)\rho }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8dfb77db7ce73098fe8cb4358ea7d0527a139907) It can be rearranged as: ![Image 38: {\displaystyle 1-{\frac {RT_{\text{sat}}}{P_{\text{sat}}}}\left(1+B\rho +C\rho ^{2}\right)\rho =0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6651c8522f7308aa88166eb5c01a35d17fae2b6a) The factor ![Image 39: {\displaystyle RT_{\text{sat}}/P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/87497c5bd7bd241eb9b0a1e167c880c693ffbfb9) is the volume of saturated gas according to the [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law "Ideal gas law"), and can be given a unique name ![Image 40: {\displaystyle v^{\text{id}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ea0f922ea68c66f6cc0c459b6b771c9444ab842d): ![Image 41: {\displaystyle v^{\text{id}}={\frac {RT_{\text{sat}}}{P_{\text{sat}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0de74a64521fb63b75f7651cf2d9de8ebf50e4be) In the saturation region, the cubic equation has three roots, and can be written alternatively as: ![Image 42: {\displaystyle \left(1-v_{\text{l}}\rho \right)\left(1-v_{\text{m}}\rho \right)\left(1-v_{\text{g}}\rho \right)=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fb8b21c08f54390407d7ad8d4c18126931b5362f) which can be expanded as: ![Image 43: {\displaystyle 1-\left(v_{\text{l}}+v_{\text{g}}+v_{m}\right)\rho +\left(v_{\text{l}}v_{\text{g}}+v_{\text{g}}v_{\text{m}}+v_{\text{m}}v_{\text{l}}\right)\rho ^{2}-v_{\text{l}}v_{\text{g}}v_{\text{m}}\rho ^{3}=0}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1fdd71c16e05063f8064b068afce86d92e25fe83)![Image 44: {\displaystyle v_{\text{m}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/287e8cd84be31145d91672af047a8f927dc07b35) is a volume of an unstable state between ![Image 45: {\displaystyle v_{\text{l}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33eaf96c44e80386e3169a7f8d9bc9688dd2b26b) and ![Image 46: {\displaystyle v_{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bfb34e5f296946ac152255310520ad4015a5d0c3). The cubic equations are identical. Therefore, from the linear terms in these equations, ![Image 47: {\displaystyle v_{m}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e39c47348c7acfafbf415f12afaaff6e0a0900ca) can be solved: ![Image 48: {\displaystyle v_{\text{m}}=v^{\text{id}}-v_{\text{l}}-v_{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/db93f483716bd775462ed7dc099e735c69ef0af4) From the quadratic terms, _B_ can be solved: ![Image 49: {\displaystyle B=-{\frac {\left(v_{\text{l}}v_{\text{g}}+v_{\text{g}}v_{\text{m}}+v_{\text{m}}v_{\text{l}}\right)}{v^{\text{id}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/98253588181d1474e45cf0869c3c36a2a343627f) And from the cubic terms, _C_ can be solved: ![Image 50: {\displaystyle C={\frac {v_{\text{l}}v_{\text{g}}v_{\text{m}}}{v^{\text{id}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/781c953f6e1ad03f395fc113446e38f487429931) Since ![Image 51: {\displaystyle v_{\text{l}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33eaf96c44e80386e3169a7f8d9bc9688dd2b26b), ![Image 52: {\displaystyle v_{\text{g}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bfb34e5f296946ac152255310520ad4015a5d0c3) and ![Image 53: {\displaystyle P_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/de8673536be352a48affb41ad7602843987f7864) have been tabulated for many fluids with ![Image 54: {\displaystyle T_{\text{sat}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/05b300de9211a1c565e9ecaf816af66e5f50de73) as a parameter, _B_ and _C_ can be computed in the saturation region of these fluids. The results are generally in agreement with those computed from Benedict-Webb-Rubin and Starling equations of state.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Title: 5: Equation of State

URL Source: https://eng.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Chemical_Engineering/Distillation_Science_(Coleman)/05:_Equation_of_State

Published Time: 2019-02-22T18:14:14Z

Markdown Content:
1.   [![Image 1: CC](https://cdn.libretexts.net/LicenseIcons/cc-clauses/cc.svg)![Image 2: BY](https://cdn.libretexts.net/LicenseIcons/cc-clauses/by.svg)](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/)
2.   Last updated Mar 6, 2024
3.   [Save as PDF](https://eng.libretexts.org/@api/deki/pages/8113/pdf/5%253A%2bEquation%2bof%2bState.pdf "Export page as a PDF")

*   ![Image 3:  ](https://eng.libretexts.org/@api/deki/files/5319/0.jpg?revision=1)
*   [Larry Coleman](https://www.linkedin.com/in/larry-coleman-57924614/)
